0:
心經解釋
觀自在菩薩，行深般若波羅蜜多時，照見五蘊皆空，度一切苦厄。
觀世音菩薩，在進行深度菩薩智慧之解說時，清楚地指出將｢色、受、想、行、識｣五蘊都拋開，心態不被自己的主觀意念所左右，才能成為菩薩幫眾生解救一切的痛苦跟災難。
1: 舍利子，(色性是空、空性是色) 、色不異空，空不異色。
2: 舍利子(當時提問觀世音菩薩的佛陀弟子)，身處空界的菩薩在三界十方世界進行救度，包含人類所處的有形體色界要做的事情跟無形體的空界環境都是一樣的。不管有無形體的各界，都是一視同仁，沒有不同。
3: ｢宇宙十方世界眾生的外在形體及環境只是假象，本性在如來藏(空無形體的靈)。由如來藏之本性才能看到眾生的真實樣貌｣。
4: 色即是空，空即是色。受想行識，亦復如是。
5: 而要拯救各界眾生，從菩薩來看，表面的｢色相｣是不存在的。而從｢色相｣身上所衍生的感受、想法、行為、意念對菩薩來說，都一樣是以如來藏的處境為考量，依據正道標準進行度化，如此才能看到真實的樣貌作為判斷進行拯救、度化。(例如：遭受劫難時，不是以當時處境施行拯救
6: ，若是因果報應或是以磨難來鍛鍊修行，菩薩就不會伸手救援。)
7: 舍利子，是諸法空相，不生不滅、不垢不淨、不增不減。
8: 舍利子，是所有的正法、法則雖不具有形體樣貌、卻真實存在著。菩薩以正法(如八正道、十善業標準)施行度化。沒有貪嗔痴引發意念生起就不需要用正法消滅惡念、沒有貪嗔痴等污穢意識及行為就不需要去清淨、沒有任何慾望增加的念頭產生惡行就不需要去減除。
9:
是故空中無色。無受想行識。
所以身為菩薩以「正法」施行救助宇宙眾生、懲奸除惡，是不會受到任何外在形體、物質、環境因素的干擾，也不會有外在因素引發的感受、想法、行為、自我意識等五蘊的困擾而失去準則。
10:
無眼耳鼻舌身意、無色聲香味觸法。
菩薩智慧清明，自然不受眼睛、耳朵、鼻子、舌頭、身體、意念六根干擾，而從六根所得的顏色形體視覺、聲音聽覺、香臭嗅覺、各種味道味覺，身體神經的觸覺，還有意念產生的想法等六塵，都不會影響菩薩的認知判斷。
11:
無眼界。乃至無意識界。
沒有六根的誤導，自然從眼界一直到意識界產生的六根、六塵及延伸的六識，合計十八界的干擾就不會存在。
12: 無無明，亦無無明盡，乃至無老死，亦無老死盡。
13: 看透真理當了菩薩擁有智慧，就沒有十二因緣起源的｢無明｣，不會無知愚蠢陷入困擾，也因通達智慧，不斷學習，所以智慧永無止盡、不會消失。而因有智慧判斷脫離輪迴，所以十二因緣一直到最後的｢老死｣就都不再出現，也因如來藏永存(西洋說：靈魂不滅)
14: ，不會因反覆輪迴不斷發生｢老死｣無窮無盡。
15: 無苦集滅道、無智亦無得，以無所得故、菩提薩埵。
16: 身為菩薩行正見、正思惟等八正道，沒了貪嗔癡三毒所引發(集)的生、老、病、死、愛別離、怨憎會、求不得、五蘊熾盛等苦(苦)，就不用為了消滅(滅)這些苦去學佛求解脫滅苦之道(道)。不花時間只求消滅自身痛苦的知識
17: ，也不會心存冀望自我有任何所得(拋棄我執)。當心裡沒有私心在替自己圖謀任何所得之故，自然可以成就利他度人為眾生而覺悟之菩薩果位。
18: 依般若波羅蜜多故，心無罣礙，無罣礙故，無有恐怖，遠離顛倒夢想，究竟涅盤。
19: 如果自己先有當菩薩的心態以此去修行六度波羅蜜求得到彼岸的智慧，心中就不會有任何自我的牽掛跟障礙，沒有了任何的牽掛及障礙，做事就不會怕東怕西想一堆來阻撓自己修行，才能真正遠離只想到自己怕輪迴之苦求解脫卻不真心關懷眾生他人死活，說一套做一套的不實際夢想
20: ，而達到真正脫離輪迴之苦、讓自己如來藏處於安樂、圓滿、寂靜不再輪迴的環境(涅槃)。
21:
三世諸佛，依般若波羅蜜多故，得阿耨多羅三藐三菩提。
不管是過去、現在成佛、還是未來即將成佛的眾菩薩，都是依照這些修行菩薩道的方法求得智慧，得到至高無上的正等正覺。
22: 故知般若波羅蜜多，是大神咒、是大明咒、是無上咒、是無等等咒。能除一切苦，真實不虛。
23: 所以要知道追求成為菩薩的智慧，這就是成為最高神位的秘訣、是讓自己智慧清明的秘訣、是至高無上、無以倫比的秘訣、是不能說等一等、等老了有空再來做的秘訣。現在開始修行學習心態改變，就能先從化解所有痛苦開始，這是真實存在不跟你畫唬爛說假話的。
24: 故說般若波羅蜜多咒，即說咒曰：揭諦、揭諦、波羅揭諦、波羅僧揭諦、菩提薩婆訶。
25: 所以現在來告訴你修行菩薩道的心法口訣，這個口訣所要表達的意思就是：快揭開面紗看透四聖諦的真貌、快看透拋棄四聖諦帶來的困擾。要想度化成為菩薩就要看透揭去四聖諦帶來的牽絆，想當菩薩的人都要透徹了解四聖諦進而拋開，這樣才能真正開悟成就菩薩之道。
26:
般若波羅蜜多心經

唐．三藏法師玄奘譯

觀自在菩薩，行深般若波羅蜜多時，照見五蘊皆空，度一切苦厄。

舍利子，色不異空，空不異色，色即是空，空即是色，受想行識，亦復如是。

舍利子，是諸法空相，不生不滅，不垢不淨，不增不減。
27: 是故空中無色，無受想行識，無眼耳鼻舌身意，無色聲香味觸法，無眼界，乃至無意識界，無無明，亦無無明盡，乃至無老死，亦無老死盡。無苦集滅道，無智亦無得。以無所得故。
28:
菩提薩埵，依般若波羅蜜多故，心無罣礙。無罣礙故，無有恐怖，遠離顛倒夢想，究竟涅槃。三世諸佛，依般若波羅蜜多故，得阿耨多羅三藐三菩提。

故知般若波羅蜜多，是大神咒，是大明咒，是無上咒，是無等等咒，能除一切苦，真實不虛。
29:
故說般若波羅蜜多咒，即說咒曰，揭諦揭諦，波羅揭諦，波羅僧揭諦，菩提薩婆訶。

 

般若波羅蜜多心經

白話淺釋
30:
白話淺釋

凡人要度苦厄，了生死，成大覺，非從自心下手不可。但要明白自心，只依這部二百六十個字的「心經」，已經夠了。但空的道理不明白，自心的相貌也難徹了。這部「心經」，最主要是說「性空」的道理，不是世人所說的空，那是斷滅空，他們誤解佛法是消極自了的。
31:
今從經題開始，將這部「心經」分八部分，用白話來逐字逐句解釋，使世人明白「空」的真義，不至誤會造業。由此斷一切苦厄，並可發大悲平等心救世，證明佛法在社會上的大用，實是開發世界大同唯一的法寶。

經題：般若波羅蜜心經
32: 「般若」，這是梵文，我國名為大智慧，因為中國文字難盡其義，所以仍用原文，並且尊重這幾個字，所以不譯。
33: 這個般若，全是說心的妙用，上自佛，下至眾生，無不由此而成佛道，了生死，度苦厄。論其性體，是不生不滅的金剛，論其相貌，卻是無形無狀的實相，論其妙用，乃是不可測知的圓通神妙。
34: 這個般若，是人人有份的，佛和眾生都是平等的，不過佛是開了般若慧，眾生是有而不開，被無明所矇住了。
35: 至於般若兩個字，解釋卻有許多字，當云「通達世間法出世閒法，融通無礙，恰到好處，而又不執取諸法的大智慧，」才能盡其義。因為世間法人事等等，都是佛法。佛是覺義，能覺悟世上一切人情世故，盡了人道，才可成佛。總之，入世出世，只是一心，顛倒煩惱，貪瞋癡迷
36: ，貪瞋癡迷，是六道眾生的心，如能空淨自在，不固執，便是佛菩薩的心。
37:
所以離世法，便沒有佛法，離了般若，只有作孽受苦厄的分了。

「波羅」，此言彼岸，因為有個度字，所以假定一條生死河，眾生在苦惱的此岸，要度過到清淨的彼岸，用來比喻，不是真有此岸彼岸。

「蜜」，是到的意思，是到了果位了；果位是究竟涅槃，涅槃就是清淨。
38: 「多」，是上面的意思，到彼岸之上，才是究竟。現在假分五步：第一步在此岸；第二步入流，是下了渡船了，是初發心的人，亦是初果羅漢；第三步是中流，船在河中間，如聲聞緣覺；第四步到了彼岸，是十地以下的善薩，終不是究竟；必第五步上岸，「多」捨丟了船，即是捨去了法見
39: ，即是捨去了法見，掃除了執心，斯是了無罣礙的等覺菩薩和佛。
40: 「心」，心是什麼？是個影子，不能說有，不能說無，所以無形段，不過是六根（眼、耳、鼻、舌、身、意）和六塵（色、聲、香、味、觸、法）相對起了認識，叫做六識（眼識、耳識、鼻識、舌識、身識、意識），所以是集起的。就是心同外境集合而緣起的幻影
41: ，即名幻心；心中起的道理，叫做幻法；執住個幻我成個幻見，於是成熟了，就有六道生死。但造成這個生死的是幻心，要開般若智慧了脫生死的，還是要用這幻心；成到佛（涅槃），也是用這幻心，你既然知道是幻的，那麼就有幻心造成幻法，一切人事等等，六道生死涅槃
42: ，六道生死涅槃，還不是一樣是幻的？由此可覺本來沒有生死，都是冤枉造作。既無生死，就用不著涅槃了，以說諸法空相，涅槃生死等空華，即是此意。但又為什麼分真心妄心呢？這是不得巳而替初學的人說，其實心，根本不有，不可得，又分什麼真和妄呢？不過幻心不能除
43: ，人事上一切的幻用不能廢，所以權分真心妄心。
44: 真心是無心之心，何以叫無心之心呢？即是不起念時，而見聞覺知仍舊了了，卻無分別，寂然不動的，此是真心；如一起了念，分別人事，而可以心不顛倒，亦不逐境流浪，頓然歸到無心本位，此還是真心。至於念念流浪，不覺漸漸入了迷途，此名妄心，但本體勿失的。
45: 這部「心經」，就教你凜覺的法子，用智慧關照什麼是心？什麼是苦厄？又如何回歸到清淨寂滅無心之心的本位？所以名為般若波羅蜜多心經。
46: 「經」，有許多意思，如「路」，指示我們回復真心之路的；「法」，一切方法；「貫」，貫通前後的義理；「契」，契合各人的機，各事的理，有這幾種解釋。現在二百六十個字，是文字般若，指示我們關照般若的方法，照此去做，實證實相般若的究竟
47: ，總不出眾生心行中事；所以經是完全指我們自身而說的。
48: 心經共有七個翻譯，這是唐朝三藏大師玄奘新譯，文是簡單的，義是深奧的。雖有七譯，意義是一樣的；讀經當重意義，不可徒在文字上死執。此經是替大乘菩薩登佛位說的，表至高無上的佛境，意境只有自己曉得，說不出的，所以叫做無字真經。並不是真的無字
49: ，願學人自己領會自己的境界，到了如何地位，至於佛的境界，卻不是二乘人或十地以下的菩薩可以測知的。我們東土人，大乘根器多而厚，所以不論男的女的，識字不識字，都喜歡讀這個經，譬如人聞香，個個人知道香味好，但多半不知道是什麼香，而受薰是平等的
50: ，而受薰是平等的，所以不可思議。以上釋題竟。
51:
經文一：觀自在菩薩，行深般若波羅蜜多時，照見五蘊皆空，度一切苦厄。

「觀」，定下了心，運想那個道理叫做觀。這個觀，是已證到果地圓成的妙觀，不是因地初修作觀的觀，是大自在觀，般若的大機大用巳經啟發，心無能觀，亦無所觀，是能所雙忘的妙觀。
52: 「自在」，是無可無不可的自在，不是自由。自由是不肯受拘束的，但環境不如你的意思，便苦了。獨有自在，是到處能安，自然地不受環境所困，一切好壞隨緣，樂亦不喜，苦亦不惱，知道他是本來空，自己有主宰的。這個自在，是指大自在。
53: 「菩薩」，是菩提薩埵的簡稱，能自己覺悟，再能覺悟人的謂之菩薩，所以是人天的導師，為三界的善知識。三界是：（一）欲界，由人的一部份下至五道，（二）色界，指天道，（三）無色界，指禪天；總是在六道中。菩薩分在家，出家，地前，登地，十地等覺，最高是一生補處菩薩
54: ，就是佛退位後，他來接位的，如此土的彌勒佛，西方的觀世音大士。這個菩薩是指十地等覺將登佛位的大自在菩薩。
55:
「行」，心行，心中起種種妙觀妙行的大用，作種種自利利他的事業。

「深」，不是深淺的深，是不可測量的意思，圓遍廣大，究竟無上的妙行。

「般若波羅蜜多」，上面巳經解釋過了，就說菩薩的功行，巳到究竟地，登彼岸之上了。
56: 「時」，這時字關係甚大，顯明到了這個境界的時候，正是果位的時候，巳經斷除一切煩惱，度盡苦厄，沒有罣礙的了。在下兩句「照見五蘊皆空，度一切苦厄」之後的意境，點明大自在的光景，不可草草。
57: 「照見」，朗然覺照，徹見無餘的意思，是無功用的功用，毫不著意的覺照，心神會通的了。
58: 「五蘊」，指色、受、想、行、識，這五事蘊結不分，叫做五蘊；此言心和外境相蘊合，統名曰色。一個色字，包括五個字在內，並且包括外面一切一切有相相形形色色，內面無相相思想方面都在內。外境原是色，而我的眼、耳、鼻、舌、身、意也是色，外色和內色接觸了
59: ，就有個受；既受了，就要去想像他，這是想；想到了，心中一行轉念，這是行；轉出那知識來，就是識；所以受想行識四個也還是色，總是幻心幻起的作用，成就種種的幻法。這個五蘊，是眾生造孽受苦成立六道生死的資本，但也是開般若，除習氣，度苦厄，了生死的工具
60: ，了生死的工具，也就是佛菩薩成大覺度眾生的工具。同要用五蘊，只是佛菩薩能照見本空，可以善用，不被所轉，眾生反被所縛；是在覺不覺，明空不明空之別，不要指定為不好的東西，反生了偏見。
61: 「皆」，統統包盡無餘，就是一切的意思，不但人空，法亦空，連照見亦空，因為照見亦是五蘊，所以稱皆。
62: 「空」，世上的人，往往不明白空的道理，籠統說：空就是沒有了。不知「空」有空閒、虛空、空相、空義種種的分別。今分為兩種：一空相，是有相的，如空屋，人滿了，空相破了，所以「有」與「空」是相對的，這就是世人說的沒有就是空了。經上另有十八空義，不必盡說。
63: 至於佛經上所說的「空」，是空義，是性空，是本來空，是與一切萬有相和合的，不是相對的，不是沒有的，是有而空的。要明白這個空的意義，先得明白幾點：所謂宇宙間一切形形色色，山河大他，日月星辰，下至一切用物、植物、動物和我的身體，都是有相相
64: ，都是有相相，還有我的思想、道理、人事、人情、喜怒哀樂，都是無相相；一切包括在內，總名曰色，在因他上總是空的。因為以上一切色，尋不出一件是有獨立自性的。第一說有相的：拿布來比，布沒有獨立自性，變成為布的，須依於紗線而成，紗線不能自為紗線，必待棉花
65: ，必待棉花，棉花不能自有，必由種子，種子不能自種，必賴人工天時地肥等等。不必分析開來才空，在未成布成紗前，及正有布有紗時，他的本身是由眾緣和合而成，因為是因緣生，所以無有實體，求其究竟相，畢竟不可得，身體亦是如此。
66: 所以一切一切，無自性，無實體，因緣生，不可得的，所以是性空。第二說無相的，拿心來說，心是什麼？根本是不有，但只集起的是心。譬如夏天涼爽的席上，人睡得甜美之極，這時候便沒有我，沒有心，忽然蚊蟲咬了一口覺得了
67: ，這覺得的便是蚊蟲和我集合而起的心。此外一切都同此理，所以心也是無自性，因緣生，無實體，不可得的，所以是性空。因此物和心，無一不是空。但是有而空，是幻有的，這是性空，和一切一切分不開的；不是心物之外另有個空，也不是這個是空，那個不是空的。所以說到色
68: ，即不能離開空，說到空，就不能離開一切色。但要認明卻是緣生幻有，又須切實知道這個空是因地本來空，是性空，非眼耳可以見聞，其義實空。
69: 既決定知道一切一切是本空而幻有，那又何必執取當他是實呢？但世上一切人事，如何可廢，我仍隨緣應付，不是麻木無心，只是勿住，行雲流水的到處自在，這才是真心空。佛說空是這個道理，世上盲目妄加批評，豈不可惜！世人果能明空，自然心勿執取，那貪得心，瞋恨心，癡迷心
70: ，瞋恨心，癡迷心，自不會深入，天下沒有極端的爭奪了。佛法豈不是社會上最大的利賴，有什麼迷信可說呢！又修行人往往有口頭禪，說：「莫著了空！」這是怕他執著空見，正因為他根本不曾明空，總在空有二見上作道理，格外攪擾不清了。所以明空則破色，破色則心空
71: ，破色則心空，這是斷苦厄的第一法門！
72:
「度」，超脫的意思，就是登彼岸之上，法見都淨了也。

「一切」，包羅所有，淨盡無餘，凡有相無相，人我法我種種苦厄，盡包在內。
73: 「苦厄」，身上的痛苦，心上的不安，有相無相，粗細微細，都是苦厄。其實全由心起，我果無心，苦在何處？心果無見，厄在何處？不是不知，不是不受；因為有智慧知道本來空，能夠知而有若無知，受而等於不受；譬如兩個人同時受苦，一個擋不住，甚至苦上加苦
74: ，甚至苦上加苦，因苦成病；一個卻無所謂，心不著意，便無苦厄了。
75: 以上四句，判為總持分，是第一段，總三藏十二部經一切法，持無量義，亦是此經綱領。通了這四句，就明白心經宗旨了。照此做去，自然度苦厄，了生死，出三界，成佛道，綽乎有餘的了。凡不明心要的人，總在文字上會，不肯從自心上會，弄得沒有辦法時，只好今日求佛，明日求法
76: ，明日求法，下此者.，求福報，求神通，死要一個有相的憑據，離佛道更遠了。深入迷途，豈不可痛！
77:
經文二：舍利子，色不異空，空不異色，色即是空，空即是色，受想行識，亦復如是。

「舍利子」，佛弟子的名字，即是舍利弗；在聲聞乘中，他是智慧第一。
78: 「色不異空，空不異色，色即是空，空即是色，受想行識，亦復如是」，首四句實是一個意思，總是說色空不二的道理。初說不異，說沒有兩樣的，還是方便的說；後說即是，是說就是一個，不能分的，是究竟說，斬金截鐵，毫無猶豫。色一個字，不單是代表五蘊
79: ，不單是代表五蘊，連外面宇宙萬有形形色色都包在內。因為宇宙萬有，就沒有離了我的性海，渾同一體，盡是色，而我的受、想、行、識，是無相相，也是色。這內外兩種色，都是因緣生，無自性，無實體，不可得，根本是性空。現下雖是幻有，畢竟不可得的，所以即色即空
80: ，所以即色即空，並不是色之外另有個空。參透上面所說的空義，就知道這個意義了。所以心的形形種種，亦是五蘊流轉，而色的形形種種，全似空華的亂起亂滅，如電影的一幕一幕，總是有而不可得。你莫把這四句看作玄妙，實是極普通極尋常的道理。你只認明『一切是因緣生，無自性
81: ，無自性，無實體，不可得，所以是性空』。不但色如是，受、想、行、識四蘊也如是，不但五蘊如是，宇宙萬有的有相相，和下面一切法，如十八界，十二因緣，四諦法，六度萬行的智得等，是無相相，一切皆復如是的性空。但是凡夫執有，所以說色不異空；二乘又執空
82: ，所以說空不異色；還有菩薩未曾會通不二的，所以說色即是空，空即是色，總是破他們的法見。倘明白法見也是本空，就了無罣礙的了。
83:
以上七句判為色空分，為第二段，用以會通色空不二的道理。

經文三：舍利子，是諸法空相，不生不滅，不垢不淨，不增不減。

「舍利子」，此時要點到本來上，在緊要關頭了，故又呼其名而告之，是鄭重的意思。
84: 「是諸法空相」，法是什麼？是心影，是心中緣起的種種道理。如果沒有對象，也就沒有心沒有法了，所以是因緣生、生而不生，無自性，無實體，不可得，本來是空，不是造作出來的空。古人說：.心生法生，心滅法滅，心既是幻，法豈是真！諸法是說一切法，就是一切心。世上的人
85: ，總是以心緣心，以法緣法，不知本空，遂當他實有，彼此固執住了，爭執就此多了。這個相字，應作義字解，下而正點到不生不滅的原理。
86: 「不生不滅」，佛經上最不容易了解的就是這一句，須知宇宙間一切一切連我的思想五蘊等等，都是不生不滅的。因為一切是：（一）不自生，如上面說布不能自生為布，是無自性的，須賴眾緣和合而生。（二）不他生，不是單靠他緣，還不能離我這個布
87: ，所以也不是他生。那麼是（三）共生的了？不，也不是共生，因為兩面也都是緣生，兩無實體，只是一個偶合，所以也不是共生。（四）不無因生，現在的假相，似乎是生，但必由因成果，沒有可以成布的因，就沒有成布的果。以此類椎，一切一切是不生的，現在雖有相
88: ，現在雖有相，終是生而不生的。既不生，即不滅，但現在的假相，卻有個假滅，只是不自滅，如布燒成灰，布不能自燒，不他滅，雖有火燒，終不能離了布，不共滅，不無因滅，都是一個理，可以推想得到的。
89: 「不垢不淨，不增不減」，因為不生不滅，所以垢淨、增減、長短、是非、好壞、來去，一對一對的都是因分別而緣生，統統是幻有不可得，所有的和，本來是空相，因世事無一不由相對而成，苦惱也由相對而立。倘知根本是因緣生，無自性，無實體，不可得，根本是生而不生
90: ，根本是生而不生，不過暫時有這個虛妄相，那又何必執為實體呢？既不執有，亦不廢有，即一切法，離一切法，既此用，離此用，心如長空萬里，包羅一切，自在無住，此是諸法空相的本來面目，亦即無心可心的本來面目。但眾生久已不知的了，有全不知者是六道眾生，半知者是二乘
91: ，半知者是二乘，知而未徹者是菩薩，都是有罣礙，所謂有五部，有此岸，有入流，有中流，有彼岸而未登岸上種種。
92:
以上五句，判為本來分，為第三段，修行人最要緊是這一點，切勿忽過。

經文四：是故空中無色，無受想行識，無眼耳鼻舌身意，無色聲香味觸法，無眼界，乃至無意識界，無無明，亦無無明盡，乃至無老死，亦無老死盡。無苦集滅道，無智亦無得，以無所得故。
93: 「是故」，此是決定的口氣。「空中無色，無受想行識，無眼耳鼻舌身意，無色聲香味觸法，無眼界，乃至無意識界」，
94: 既明白了空的道理，那麼空之中還有什麼實體可得呢？這「無」字有兩個解釋：.一是無有，是根本不有的意思。二是毋的意思。因為現在雖有幻相，但畢竟是無，毋庸執取以為實有而生法見，添許多煩惱。所以五蘊（色、受、想、行、識）
95: ，六根（眼、耳、鼻、舌、身、意）六塵（色、聲、香、味、觸、法）這是十二入，再加上六識（眼識、耳識、鼻識、舌識、身識、意識）共為十八界，都是不可得，因為是緣生的，無自性的，無實體的，不可得的。然而人既有此幻身，自有幻心作用，不能斷滅，佛菩窿也要用以度眾生
96: ，救世間無量苦，我人正要用此以開般若，了生死，出三界，不過聖人明白本來空，所以無法執；眾生迷了，遂生顛倒，這是眾生的大罣礙。因為地獄眾生，罣礙在具足多分貪瞋癡，鬼道罣礙於多分的貪，畜道罣礙於多分的癡，魔道罣礙於多分的瞋，人道罣礙於半分的貪瞋癡
97: ，天道罣礙於少分的貪。這貪、瞋、癡三毒，都由六根六塵六識而起，只一空字可以化除一切煩惱罣礙。化除了，當下即是菩提，所以煩惱菩提，同是這個東西。
98:
「無無明，亦無無明盡，乃至無老死，亦無老死盡」，這是緣覺（即辟支佛，是不曾聞到佛法而借因緣覺悟的）執取十二因緣法而生罣礙，他不知道諸法空相。既說是因緣，可見是緣生不實，但伊不能明空，被法見縛住了，不得自在。

那十二因緣即是：
99:
一、無明：是過去的根本煩惱，只要碰到緣就動了。緣就轉下去的意思。

二、無明緣行：行是行動，做種種或善或惡的行業。

三、行緣識：由於過去的行業，而起現世受胎的一念，是因認識而成為果的。

四、識緣名色：在胎中已有形體而有名色。
100:
五、名色緣六入：是六根具足，可以和六塵相對的了。

六、六入緣觸：是出胎後對於一切有所接觸了。

七、觸緣受：接觸之後，就受苦受集而生種種感覺。

八、受緣愛：如成年以後，就有強盛的愛慾。

九、愛緣取：有了愛慾，就想去取得，心去四面馳求。
101:
十、取緣有：取得就有了，是有業成就的果位。

十一、有緣生：這是成立了，生生不已，轉入未來。

十二、生緣老死：有生就有滅，一切本是夢幻泡影，終必變減，老死是這一段生死的果。
102: 但只是無明未滅，再來一轉，生生世世轉輾不已，遂有六道輪迴，總是無明作祟。乃至兩個字，是由無明跳至老死，中間咯去十位。這十二因緣，位位都依據無明作主，不知皆是妄心幻法緣起，根本無有。盡者，極也，就是無之極也。言無亦無有也
103: ，是絕對不可得的意思。所以無明非有實體，如空中華，夢中事，夢中非無，及至夢醒，了不可得。可憐眾生不能斷無明，緣緣而下，無有窮期，無非是惑業苦。緣覺雖已悟到十二因緣，原是假有的一合相，但以為是定法不移，所以法見不淨而生罣礙。
104: 「無苦集滅道」，這是聲聞執取四諦法，而生罣礙。苦、集、滅、道，是名四諦，就是四種重要的道理。苦是身心逼迫不安。眾生身有三苦：老、病、死。心有三苦：貪、瞋、癡。後世有三苦：地獄、鬼、畜生。更有三災八難苦、壞苦、行苦、苦苦、不知足苦、不安命苦、心無寄託苦
105: ，這是苦諦。卻是三界六道生死苦果，無不由心和境集合而成，這是集諦。滅是消滅的意思，斷一切苦，歸到清淨寂滅。因為結業既滅，則無生死的患累，這是滅諦。但要滅除那集合的諸苦，必得有個道理，道是正道；做到正道，必要助道，助其離一切苦，到涅槃樂
106: ，到涅槃樂，這是道諦。聲聞執此法見以為究竟，所以分段生死，或者可了，變易生死卻不易了。倘明本來空，則知此四諦法，不過一時的緣生，不但是果上色空，實是因上色空，不必執取，便無罣礙了。
107: 「無智亦無得」，這是菩薩的罣礙。菩薩執取六度萬行諸法，以為確有智慧可得，有眾生可度，有佛可成，心中不免具此波羅蜜的行相，微細的法見不曾淨，所以不到究竟涅槃地。從前阿難問佛如何是煩惱地獄種性？佛說行六波羅蜜行是煩惱地獄種，如我能佈施
108: ，如我能佈施，因見他人不肯佈施而生厭惡，是煩惱地獄種，我能持戒等等，因見別人不能持戒等等，心生厭恨，是煩惱地獄種。這就是彌陀經上說的見濁，是名染法，染糊塗了。況且有智無智，都是幻心作用，分別為二：同是性空，更有何法可得？世尊昔在燃燈佛所得佛授記，成無上菩提
109: ，成無上菩提，世尊當時並不取以為勝，因為知道性空。實無少法可得，不過名為菩提而已。所以菩薩必到法無我的時侯，才是罣礙淨盡。
110:
「以無所得故」，這是總結一句，極言上面五蘊、十八界、十二因緣、四諦法、六度智得一切本空，仔細推求，實無所得。

以上十三句判為法用分，為第四段，說空了之後，般若法用自然啟發，也不受法縛了。
111: 經文五：菩提薩埵，依般若波羅蜜多故，心無罣礙。無罣礙故，無有恐怖，遠離顛倒夢想，究竟涅槃。三世諸佛，依般若波羅蜜多故，得阿耨多羅三藐三菩提。
112: 「菩提薩埵」，簡稱就是菩薩，此指已登佛位的明心菩薩，又名開士、大士，又薩埵譯為精進勇猛，堪以荷擔如來事業的人。
113: 「依般若波羅蜜多故」，他因為依自性的金剛般若，能夠超超登彼岸的緣故，所以有下面實證的受用。我們應該知道修行不是圖利，更不能圖名，名利是生死最毒的藥，名利的心不死，永無出頭的日子。因此因地要正，總要在自性上打算，老老實實，真參實究，決不要在神通奇特
114: ，出語玄妙上求，絲毫擋不住生死的。菩薩尚不能離開般若，何況我輩，離了般若之外，更有何法？這是成佛的根本條件，肯向這條法上走的，才是有智慧的人，此生決可成就。
115: 「心無罣礙」，這個心，是毫無罣礙，人空法空，寂滅輕安的大自在心，視世間出世間一切一切皆量等虛空，無有邊際，包羅萬有，了無罣礙。心且不有，罣礙何依？苦厄安在？
116: 「無罣礙故，無有恐怖，遠離顛倒夢想」，心裏既是淨空無見，白天沒有想像，夜間自無亂夢，正如千眼千手，圓照十方，豈有顛倒，凡人恐怖，先有一個得失心，就是有我的果，正是六道生死的種性。如能心空法空，登於佛位，兩個生死已了。菩薩再來世間，是大悲願力，不是業力
117: ，不是業力，自然沒有恐怖，顛倒夢想，都遠離了，到了生滅滅已，寂滅為樂的境界了。
118: 「究竟涅槃」，這涅槃是清淨的意思。二乘人是有餘涅槃，不是究竟；這究竟涅槃是佛位，名為無餘涅槃，連涅槃亦不可得。所謂成了佛，也沒有成佛的法見。本來涅槃是對生死說的，既本來沒有生死，亦安有涅槃，不過同是個假名罷了。這是菩薩的果德。
119: 「三世諸佛」，無論現在佛，過去佛，未來佛，統包括三世一切諸佛，不問已成未成，都是一體平等。須知釋迦彌陀是果上佛，我和六道眾生是因上佛，性自平等，所以不可自棄，也不可輕人。
120: 「依般若波羅蜜多故，得阿耨多羅三藐三菩提」，三世諸佛，也無不由此法門而得無上菩提；一切大智慧，無不由自性佛母所生，生是啟發的意思。這個得，正是無得之得，必得心中了無可得，然後本來的面目斯得。此時無人，無我，無眾生，無壽者，寂然不動，而妙用恆沙，由此啟發
121: ，由此啟發，這是佛的果德。阿耨多羅是無上。三藐是正等，三菩提是正覺；就是無上正等正覺，是言佛的意境。你想連佛也不能離此法門，眾生豈可自外，另覓途徑，豈非顛倒！所以不自求而他求，都是因地不正，適以自誤！
122: 以上十句判為果德分，為第五段，是說到果德地位，一切罣礙才算淨盡，才是究竟涅槃，都賴觀空成就，並無別法。又以上可算是上半部心經，專說此法無實。下面再翻身過來說個無虛，金剛經說：.「此法無實無虛。」要人不要執實，也不要執虛，正現般若無住的妙用。若再深一層講
123: ，心既不有，法於何依？既沒有法，更談不到無實無虛的了；所以說，涅槃生死等空華。
124: 經文六：故知般若波羅蜜多，是大神咒，是大明咒，是無上咒，是無等等咒，能除一切苦，真實不虛。
125: 「故知般若波羅蜜多」，以下是轉人無虛，點明一知字的妙用。這知字是靈照覺知，表明悟後的意境，彷彿是轉而為有，不知這知字也是法，也是性空，一時的緣生，暫時的法用，即是知而無知，生而不生，所以不明無生的道理，就不能證知真空的道理。前說一空字，是般若的體
126: ，是般若的體，此說一知字，是般若的用。所以表般若的至德，無可形容，無可言表，至此言語道斷，心行處滅；惟有神會，惟有讚歎，正是冷暖自知的時候。
127: 「是大神咒，是大明咒，是無上咒，是無等等咒，能除一切苦，真實不虛」，這六句是讚歎的辭旬。咒是蜜意，以決定如是曰咒，如軍令嚴速曰咒。以無所不包謂之大，以無所不通謂之神；以無所不照謂之明，以無可比對無可再加謂之無上；以畢竟平等謂之無等等；空不偏空，有不著有
128: ，有不著有，於寂滅無住的性體中，能啟發恆沙妙用。六祖云：何期自性本不生滅，本不動搖；何其自性能生萬法。前為無實之體，此為無虛之用；故能除一切苦，真實不虛。你想世上的人，沒一個人沒有罣礙的痛苦，哪一個人能離了佛法，佛法又何曾迷信呢！
129: 以上七句判為證知分，分第六段，要親證才知這個境界，不是靠文字可以得知的。所以得知的必須要真參實究，從自性上用功，經是不過借來考證罷了。總之，心通才是最大神通，但心不空就不能通，不通就不能明，不明則一切智慧被無明所覆，不能啟發。這一分是說心到了真空的境界
130: ，自然有許多力量；不是有苦再除，卻使一切苦厄無所依附，根本無苦厄了。
131: 經文七：故說般若波羅蜜多咒，即說咒曰，揭諦揭諦，波羅揭諦，波羅僧揭諦，菩提薩婆訶。
132: 「故說般若波羅蜜多咒，即說咒曰，揭諦揭諦，波羅揭諦，波羅僧揭諦，菩提薩婆訶」，梵咒本來不許翻譯的，因為怕持的人看了解釋，反而添知見，心亂了。但此經是自利利他的，終不能忘記眾生，離了大悲本願。姑將咒義咯述一二：揭諦揭諦，是說度過去呀！度過去呀！波羅揭諦
133: ，是向彼岸度過去呀！波羅僧揭諦，是彼岸大家度過去呀！菩提薩婆訶，是速速證到菩提呀！
134: 以上六句判為秘密分，為第七段，只有自已知道，沒法出口的意思。
135: 佛說的三藏十二部，總是說個心，這心經是說心內精華。大凡人有七個心，每每自己不知道的，那六個是六道心，每日流轉勿停，忽而天道心，忽而人道心，又忽而三惡道心，總是無主的逐境流浪心。下等的人，並且不知道什麼是叫做心，中等的人才知道善心惡心的分別心
136: ，上等人是多有向上的心，可以得人天的好果。
137: 還有第七個心是空心，是無上的心，是無住的心，是有主的心，是清淨自在的心，這個心不是修證到是不會知道的，連二乘人和權乘菩薩也不會知道的。佛說，微生蟲到處可去，只是火裏不能去。眾生的心到處可緣，只是不肯向般若上去，就是不知道那第七個心。這個心是出世的心
138: ，明了這個心，去成佛就不遠了。
139: 眾生在此岸，是六個心，超登彼岸，便是那第七個無心的心，正是毫無罣礙的心了。但人不從六個心上下手，就不能出世，要從煩惱上參透，罣礙上打開，方可成佛，譬如人已落在泥坑裏，必要從泥裏拔出來
140: ，所以世法正是出世的資糧。人先要明白煩惱是什麼？還是我的六個心。你且息下了，心空無著，才見那無心的心了。從來修佛道的人，以為是出世看得輕，不值得理他，平時就不在人事上練心，於做人道理全不講究。
141: 孝悌是根本，忠信是法用，是盡人道的根基，正是成佛的本錢。大乘佛法，首重根本，所以能一路直人，一竿到底，中間不會背師忘道，自入歧途。你想五蘊法見都空了，那貪根已斷，名利心又附在何處呢？
142: 所以奉勸世人讀經要照經去做，第一步求得明心的法門，一門深入，見到了實相，自然般若開了，第二步有了辦法，在人事上磨練，掃蕩習氣；此時有進無退，直到成佛。
143: 但此生只可見性成佛，除淨習氣，還得多世，不用功還要遲下去，不過見性後，就世世不退轉了。這個經是文字般若，指示我們的法行；須自作觀行，即是觀照般若；啟發般若後，見到自性，開了智慧，這是實相般若，此實歸宗的唯一的門路，由此永斷無明，了脫生死，文雖二百六十個字
144: ，足以蕩空掃有，實證菩提，菩薩與三世佛，均不能出此範圍。
145:
心經雖有七譯，經義實是不二，彙萬法以歸一，更破一以歸宗，無心可心，無經可說；世尊說法四十九年，不曾說一個字，就是點明一切性空的道理。

願行者須從自性的道理上會，不要在文字的道理上會，把心空了，才可以和心經相印，是謂印心。

講心經竟。
147: As we know, Buddhism has a long history of more than 2,500 years.
148:
In this long time, since the Buddha turned the Dharma Wheel and
then passed into nirvana, great masters in both Tibetan and Han
149:
Buddhism have all attached great importance to the Heart Sutra,
the shortest scripture on the perfection of wisdom.
150: For example, the main doctrinal traditions of Tibetan Buddhism,
151: with the four great traditions of the Gelug, the Sakya, the Kagyu,
152:
the Nyingma, as well as the Jonang, all attach great importance
to the Prajnaparamita-Hrdaya Sutra, commonly known as the Heart
153: Sutra. The Heart Sutra is an indispensable scripture in any master’s
154: repertoire of teachings and practices. Most Dharma practitioners
155: in Tibetan Buddhism adopt it in their collections of recitations and
156:
chant it regularly, either early in the morning, late in the evening,
or at any other time.
157:
10
In Tibetan people’s daily life, such as performing ceremonies for
158: the dead, in the rituals of consecrations, in the practice of animal
159: liberation, and even in building a new house, the Heart Sutra plays
160: an essential role. As long as one recites the Heart Sutra, the activity
161: as a whole will be successfully complete, and no adverse conditions
162:
due to harmful demons will arise during the activity. The Heart
Sutra is often recited together with a supplemental section for
163: dokpa, the practice of averting harm and negativity.
164: This is also clear in Han Buddhism. Regardless of the Pure Land or
165: the Chan tradition, or the other traditions, all monasteries and all
166: eminent masters hold the Heart Sutra in the highest regard. This
167:
scripture has long been commonly practiced in many traditions in
China.
168: Not only is it true in the regions where Mahayana ﬂourishes, the
169: Heart Sutra is also held in high regard everywhere else. The monks
170: of the Southern traditions of Buddhism in Thailand and Sri Lanka
171: also chant the Heart Sutra as their daily practice. Back to 1999, a Thai
172: master came to visit Larung Gar, and he told Khenpo Sodargye
173:
that he carried the Heart Sutra in the collection of recitations with
him at all times.
175: Although the Heart Sutra is very short, compared with the Diamond
176: Sutra or other scriptures on the perfection of wisdom, why is it so
177: important and how did it come to receive such a consideration?
178:
After the Buddha attained enlightenment, he turned the Dharma
Wheel of the teachings three times during a period of more than
179: forty years, explaining to living beings the eighty-four thousand
180: teachings. Among the three turnings of the Dharma Wheel, in the
181: ﬁrst the Buddha elucidated the teaching on the four noble truths
182: of suﬀering, origins, cessation, and the path; in the second turning
183:
of the Dharma Wheel, the Buddha revealed the teachings on the
perfection of wisdom and emptiness; and during the third turning
184:
of the Dharma Wheel, he disclosed the luminous nature of the
essence of the tathagatas.
185: In the Buddhadharma as a whole, the most profound and most
186: important of the three wheels of the teachings is the content of the
187:
12
second wheel. But why is it the most important? Because it reveals
188: the true aspect of all phenomena and shows the path that the living
189: beings of the three realms must follow in order to attain liberation.
190:
And the collection of all topics included in the second wheel of the
teachings is the entire set of the Prajnaparamita sutras.
191:
When Buddha Shakyamuni was soon to enter nirvana, he passed on
the eighty-four thousand teachings to Ananda. He then solemnly
192: addressed him, declaring that, “I will not blame you if you forget
193: entirely, or if you damage completely, the eighty-four thousand
194: teachings, except for the perfection of wisdom. But if you misplace
195: a single line of the perfection of wisdom, I will hold you personally
196: responsible for it.” This passage illustrates how, setting apart the
197:
perfection of wisdom, the eighty-four thousand teachings as a
whole are not as important in content as a single verse on the
199: The Prajnaparamita sutras are of three types, including the long,
200: middle, and short discourses on the perfection of wisdom. The long
201: Prajnaparamita sutra has one hundred thousand lines. The Tibetan
202: edition of the large Prajnaparamita sutra makes twelve heavy cases.
203:
The middle Prajnaparamita sutra has twenty-ﬁve thousand lines;
and the short Prajnaparamita sutra has eight thousand lines.
204:
13
If we condense the essential meaning of the Prajnaparamita sutras,
205:
we obtain the Heart Sutra. So it is the essence, the heart, and
the core of the Buddhadharma. Put another way, the contents
206: of the Heart Sutra actually cover all the eighty-four thousand
207: teachings. It is the scripture whose text is the shortest and yet
208:
whose doctrinal principles are the deepest and subtlest. Indeed,
it can be described as “a mustard seed containing Mount Meru”.
209:
Just like modern technology enabling the compression of a large
amount of information into a tiny compact disc, the extremely
210:
concise Heart Sutra condenses the essence of all Buddhadharma.
That’s why generations of scholars have held the Heart Sutra in
211:
such an extraordinary consideration. It is the essence of the entire
Buddhadharma.
212: Our lifespan and energy are limited. Therefore, even if we wish
213:
to study the eighty-four thousand teachings as a whole, we will
ﬁnd it impossible to know the entire Buddhadharma thoroughly
214: and with no obstructions. However, if we could grasp the main
215: points, we could then eﬀectively bring out the essentials. From this
216: perspective, to study the Heart Sutra is the wisest choice.
217:
14
Who Are Able to Study the
Heart Sutra?
218: Certainly, to be able to meet this sublime teaching as a follower of
219: the Buddha is the result of the extensive accumulation of merit in
220: the past numerous eons. As it is said in Buddhist scriptures, anyone
221:
who meets the Buddhadharma of the Mahayana must have formed
a subtle connection with the Buddha’s teaching in previous lives.
222: Lacking such a supreme connection, it will be utterly impossible
223: to hear a single word, or a line, of the teachings on the perfection
224: of wisdom even in dreams, let alone to reﬂect about them, or even
225:
further, to engage in their practice. Therefore, we should develop a
mind of incomparable joy and care for this scripture.
226: In Longchenpa’s Treasury of Instructions, he stated, “Believing in and
227: hearing the Buddhadharma, feeling joy and performing eulogies,
228: as well as even slightly engaging in the correct teaching, sow the
229: seeds of liberation leading away from cyclic existence.” Anytime
230: one believes in and listens to Buddhist scriptures, rejoicing and
231:
15
praising them, one accumulates immeasurable merits. Therefore,
232:
whether or not you are Buddhist, if you chant the Heart Sutra
you will develop an auspicious connection with the teachings on
234:
In Buddhist scriptures it is also said that anyone who learns about
emptiness must be someone who has great merit and wisdom.
235:
Anyone who wishes to know whether one has a connection with
the teachings of emptiness, and whether the seed of emptiness has
236: already ripened in one’s mental continuum, can draw a conclusion
237: based on the feeling one has after hearing about it: if, having heard
238: the Heart Sutra, one has goose bumps, is moved to tears, and is
239: unable to control the joy in one’s heart, this proves that one has
240: had a connection with the teachings on emptiness in previous lives;
241: if not so, one was far removed from the teachings on emptiness.
242: There’re a famous story of Lord Atisha. Once two monks training in
243: the Southern traditions of Buddhism came to Atisha on account of
244: his reputation in order to request the transmission of the teachings
245: from him. To begin, Atisha taught them the teaching of the four
246: noble truths and the view of selﬂessness of persons. In hearing the
247:
teachings, the two monks were so happy that their face covered
in smiles, and repeatedly nodded their head in agreement. Atisha
248:
then taught them the selﬂessness of phenomena and the contents
of the Heart Sutra. Who would have imagined that, after hearing
249:
16
these teachings, they became terriﬁed, and promptly begged Atisha
250: to stop, saying: “Great sage! Great master! Please stop teaching us,
251:
you’re frightening us!” Later on, despite further requests, Atisha
ignored them. Eventually, the two monks had no choice but to
253:
Deeply moved, Atisha then said: “Merely receiving and keeping
the pure vows of the basic vehicle bears no great signiﬁcance,
254: for one should listen extensively and expand one’s learning. In
255: particular, one should understand the Prajnaparamita sutras. If not
256: so, in no way will one understand the Buddha’s perfect wisdom.”
257: In general, as one becomes familiar with the Buddha’s teaching,
258: it is rather easy to accept the teachings of the vehicles of humans
259:
and gods such as “virtue has a pleasant reward, non-virtue has
a non-pleasant reward”. In studying the profound teachings on
260: emptiness in such scriptures as the Heart Sutra, it is necessary to
261: have a sense of one’s capacity. The same principles that apply to
262: the Great Perfection also apply to the teachings on emptiness of
263:
the perfection of wisdom. If you are unable to accept them, not
only will they be of any beneﬁt, but they could also harm you.
264: Everyone must treat this issue with caution, and with conscientious
265: introspection, to ensure that one is a suitable vessel to listen and
266: practice the teachings on emptiness. But, as Khenpo Sodargye said,
267: everyone in the audience must already have a connection with the
268:
17
teachings on emptiness. If not so, one would not be able to hear
269: about the Heart Sutra at all.
270:
18
How to Study the                Heart Sutra?
271: The Heart Sutra touches upon many ideas concerning the conven-
272: tional aspect of phenomena and the ultimate aspect of reality. If
273:
one genuinely wishes to understand these ideas, not only must one
become proﬁcient in the meanings implied in the long, middle,
274: and short scriptures on the perfection of wisdom, there are still
275: two texts that one must study: the one is the Abhidharmakosa (A
276: Treasury of Abhidharma) and the other is the Root Verses on the Middle
277: Way. With no prior study of these two works, we will be unable
278:
to grasp the contents of the perfection of wisdom, for many of its
ideas cannot be explained clearly in only a few words.
279: In the Abhidharmakosa we can learn about such concepts as the ﬁve
280: aggregates, the twelve sense bases, the eighteen constituents, the
281: twelve links of dependent origination, and the four noble truths;
282: but still, we will not ascertain the emptiness of these notions. After
283:
Buddha Shakyamuni passed into ﬁnal nirvana, Nagarjuna was the
great scholar who, as prophesied by the Buddha himself in quite a
284:
19
few scriptures, gathered and elucidated the Prajnaparamita sutras.
285:
The most important of Nagarjuna’s works is the Root Verses on the
Middle Way.
286:
Moreover, the works that comment and explain this text and its
underlying intention are the works by Nagarjuna’s direct disci-
287:
ple—Acharya Aryadeva’s  Four Hundred Stanzas, together with
Acharya Chandrakirti’s Prasannapada (Clear Words) and Madhya-
288:
makavatara (Entrance into the Middle Way). Through the study of
such Madhyamika works, we will be able to understand that all
289: of the aforementioned concepts are empty. Once we have laid this
290:
foundation, learning the contents of the Heart Sutra will become
an easy and smooth task.
291:
However, because of the limitations imposed by our teaching
schedule, we’re unable to follow a thorough commentary on the
292:
profound and vast meanings of the Heart Sutra. Here we will only
touch on the main points, commenting on the exterior meanings
293:
in a simple and cursory way: while certain neophytes will sow
the seed of wisdom, everyone will be able to understand the main
295:
20
About the Different Versions
of the      Heart Sutra
296: There are diﬀerent versions of the Heart Sutra. Despite minor vari-
297: ations concerning the name of each translation, and despite slight
298: diﬀerences in the texts, the main points remain fundamentally the
299: same. The focus of the debate on the diﬀerence concerns only the
300: opening and the closing portions of the translations. The transla-
301: tion by Xuanzang lack these two portions, which are included in
302: other translations. Some believe that the translation by Xuanzang
303: are inconsistent. So they discredit this shorter version, and believe
304: that it is not coherent. Still others believe on the contrary that the
305:
textual editions lacking coherence are the longer versions with the
opening and closing portions.
306: Indeed, we should trust both shorter version and longer versions,
307: for the two types are not mutually exclusive, and we need not
308: chose one and reject the other. Based on reliable historical records,
309: the most popular and most authoritative Heart Sutra in the Tibetan
310:
21
language was translated directly into Tibetan from Sanskrit. Its
311: translator Vimalamitra is an extraordinary translator, also one of
312:
the great lineage masters of the Great Perfection in the Nyingma
tradition.
313: There could be three reasons that Xuanzang’s translation diﬀers
314: from other translations. First, it might be due to diﬀerences in the
315: original Sanskrit texts. Second, it is possible that the teaching spo-
316: ken by the Buddha is somewhat diﬀerent when heard by diﬀerent
317: living beings. For example, when the Buddha set forth the wheel of
318: the teaching at Vulture Peak, about one hundred thousand of his
319: disciples were present. While each disciple possessed the Dharani
320:
of not forgetting, nonetheless each perceived a teaching that was
not exactly the same. The Buddha proclaims diﬀerent teachings
321:
because he can address the diﬀerent interests and predispositions
of living beings.
322: The third reason is that the Sanskrit version originally employed by
323: Xuanzang should have been given to him directly by Bodhisattva
324:
Avalokiteshvara. It is mentioned in the story of Xuanzang retrieving
Buddhist scriptures in India.
325:
At the very beginning, when Xuanzang left for India to study
the Buddhadharma, he had a large following. Later, however, he
326: remained alone. When he approached the great desert, having
327:
22
overturned his water ﬂask, he lost direction, so that he and his
328: horse were unable to proceed as they fainted from thirst. For four
329:
nights and ﬁve days in a row, Xuanzang did not ingest a single
drop of water. He simply dropped dead on the desert, and chanted
330: the name of Avalokiteshvara, until, the ﬁfth night, the old horse
331: perceived the smell of water plants in the gusting breeze. Only then
332: was Xuanzang able to ﬁnd his way out of this diﬃcult situation.
333: Once he passed by a monastery. At that very moment, he happened
334: to hear someone cry out loud. As he came closer to take a look, he
335: found out that the person who cried was a monk whose entire body
336: was covered in blisters (just like leprosy today). Xuanzang was
337: fully aware of the length of his journey, still, as he saw this destitute
338:
monk, he did not hasten on with his journey. Instead, he remained
in the monastery to cure him. Later, only when the monk fully
339:
recovered from illness, did Xuanzang bid farewell and proceed
further. As Xuanzang was about to leave, in order to express his
340:
gratitude, the monk gave him a Sanskrit scripture as a gift. That
very scripture was the celebrated Heart Sutra.
341:
On the road, Xuanzang would always read this sutra, especially
when he met with adverse conditions and obstacles. As long as
342:
he recited the sutra, any adverse condition or obstacle would
immediately and completely fade away.
343:
23
The amazing thing is that along the route of his return from India,
344:
Xuanzang arranged things so that he could repay the kindness
of the monk who had given him  the Heart Sutra. Who would
345:
have thought that, as he reached the place where the monastery
was then located, not only the monk but also the monastery had
347:
It is said that the elderly monk was Avalokiteshvara, who then
manifested as a monk in order to personally give Xuanzang the
348: Sanskrit manuscript of the Heart Sutra. This statement stands to
349:
reason, for Avalokiteshvara’s power is inconceivable. In addition,
the Heart Sutra takes shape through a dialogue empowered by
350:
Buddha Shakyamuni between Shariputra and Avalokiteshvara.
Moreover, in the sutra itself all topics are entirely proclaimed
351:
by Avalokiteshvara. There is also a chance that Avalokiteshvara
manifested as a monk in order to give Xuanzang the Sanskrit
353: Therefore, the Heart Sutra translated by Xuanzang is the most
354: powerful. If one wishes to chant it, one can do so relying entirely
355:
upon Xuanzang’s translation. But in providing a commentary to
others, or when we want to thoroughly understand the meaning
356:
of the Heart Sutra, it is also admissible to have the version with the
opening and closing portions added.
357:
24
The Sublime Blessings of the
Heart Sutra
358: In Tibetan Buddhism, there is such a tradition that if certain adverse
359: conditions come up, people will chant the Heart Sutra to get rid
360: of them. For those senior monastics or elder practitioners, when
361: meeting with greatly diﬃcult situations, such as earthquakes or
362: severe disasters, they will chant the Heart Sutra. In particularly, on
363: the 29th day of the twelfth month of the Tibetan lunar calendar,
364:
everyone will chant the Heart Sutra’s dokpa liturgy of averting
harm and negativity, with the auspices to avoid all hindrances
365:
from evil spirits during the coming year by relying on the power
of emptiness from the Heart Sutra.
366: If we habitually carry the Heart Sutra with us, and if we perform
367: oﬀerings to it at our shrining room, due to the power and blessing
368: of emptiness from the Prajnaparamita, we will be able to get rid of
369:
all negative conditions. Or even if we place it by our pillow when
we sleep, we won’t have nightmares.
370:
25
Some may wonder, what is the power of blessing? Simply put,
371: what we call the power of blessing is certain kind of power that
372:
has obviously beneﬁcial eﬀects to us, yet cannot be seen with our
naked eye, for it is immaterial.
373:
There are many things that cannot be seen with the naked eye
while having practical beneﬁts. For example, medicine has the
374: power to cure, electricity has the power to charge, and, in a similar
375: way, anything has a kind of force and power. The blessings of the
376:
Heart Sutra come from the power of emptiness, the power of the
Buddha, the power of the bodhisattva Avalokiteshvara, as well
377:
as the power of ultimate truth, and, in addition, the power of
the conﬁdence that we have in the Heart Sutra. Especially when
378: we have such conﬁdence, together with all the other conditions
379: gathering together, we can certainly be blessed by the incredible
380:
power and get rid of all kinds of harm caused by evil spirits and
others. The power of the blessings is indeed inconceivable.
381: In those sutras talking about the merits of emptiness, it is often said
382: that if one carries with oneself a scripture that teaches emptiness,
383: such as the Heart Sutra, any living being who touches the scripture
384: directly or indirectly, for example, being touched by the wind that
385: brushes against the scripture, will not fall into the three lower
386: realms; likewise, if these sources of the teachings are carried with
387: a person, then any other being who touches or drinks this person’s
388:
26
bathing water will not fall into the three lower realms; and anyone
389: who chants the Heart Sutra, those beings who hear his or her voice,
390: even when quarrelling with others, will also not fall into the three
391: lower realms. Certainly, this is not to say that such beings will be
392: able to immediately attain liberation; nevertheless, the blessings
393:
from the scriptures on emptiness are inconceivable and have great
power to protect those beings from being suﬀered in the lower
395: Since we know that the merits of the teachings on emptiness are
396: quite inconceivable, we should have conﬁdence in this. If we meet
397:
with adverse conditions, hardship or any form of suﬀering during
our practice, as Khenpo Sodargye suggested, we should try to
398:
abide on the meaning of emptiness and then chant the Heart Sutra,
in this way we can overcome any kind of obscurations.
399:
27
Opening
The Title of the Sutra


The Title of the Sutra
400:
IN SANSKRIT:
   Bhagavati Prajna Paramita Hridaya Sutra
401:
IN ENGLISH:
   The Blessed Mother, the Heart of the Perfection of Wisdom
402: The full title of the Heart Sutra is Bhagavati Prajna Paramita Hridaya
403: Sutra, which means The Blessed Mother, the Heart of the Perfection
404: of Wisdom. Here Bhagavati, the Blessed Mother, is the appositive of
405:
Prajna Paramita, or in other words, Prajna Paramita is described as
Bhagavati, the Blessed Mother.
406: The literal meaning of Prajnaparamita is “wisdom gone to the other
407:
shore”. But the term prajna resists the translation as “wisdom.”
In Han Buddhism, it was not translated directly as wisdom, but
408: simply maintained its transliteration as “bo re”, because the term
409:
29
wisdom only partially explains the meaning of prajna, and does not
410: express the profound implications of the term entirely. Similarly,
411: in Tibetan Buddhism, according to King Trisong Detsen’s request,
412:
all the titles of the Prajnaparamita sutras were left in Sanskrit.
The Meaning of     Bhagavati
413: Bhagavati is the one who has achieved enlightenment, or buddha-
414: hood. This term refers not to a physically existing person, but rather
415: to the absolute state of Prajnaparamita itself. The term Bhagavati
416: has the connotation of “mother”, or it is considered as feminine
417: because, through realization of her own nature, Prajnaparamita,
418: she gives birth to the buddhas of the three times, and thus is the
419: mother of the so-called “Four Noble Children”: shravakas, pratyek-
420: abuddhas, bodhisattvas, and buddhas. Or to put it in a simple way,
421: Prajnaparamita is considered as the mother of all noble beings.
422:
Buddha Shakyamuni, teaching elsewhere in the Prajnaparamita,
says that “those people who would become shravakas must learn
423:
to practice the Prajnaparamita; those who aspire to be a pratyek-
abuddha must learn and practice the Prajnaparamita; those who
424:
would achieve bodhisattva realization must learn and practice the
Prajnaparamita; and those who would accomplish buddhahood
425: must learn and practice the Prajnaparamita.”
427:
Prajna means supreme wisdom. In Sanskrit pra means supreme
or highest, and jna means knowledge or wisdom. It is supreme
428:
wisdom because what it knows or understands is the meaning of
our true, absolute nature, and there is no meaning or knowledge
430: Paramita means beyond, or gone to the other shore. It also can
431: be translated as perfection in some contexts. So what is the other
432:
shore? From a worldly perspective, when someone has completed
the goal of one’s task, one can be said to have reached the other
433: shore. In this context, “the other shore” indicates nirvana, whereas
434: “this shore” indicates samsara. Living beings are drowning in the
435: ocean of the three realms of cyclic existence, ever unable to emerge.
436: Therefore, they are on this shore of the ocean of suﬀering. But the
437: liberation of nirvana is beyond the ocean of cyclic existence. Hence,
438: it is called the other shore. Only the Buddha has crossed to the
439: other shore, and no one else in the world has gone to the other
440: shore. All the living beings of the three realms are wandering in
441:
the ocean of suﬀering that is cyclic existence, still relatively distant
from the other shore.
442: Regardless of an expertise, a globally renowned scientist, or a
443: philosopher, or a thinker reputed for profound erudition, one can
444:
31
only be proﬁcient in the knowledge of a certain worldly ﬁeld. There
445:
is still a great diﬀerence between the wisdom of the Buddha, who
is omniscient, and the knowledge of such individuals. And even
446: with the wisdom of an arhat, they will not have reached the other
447:
shore, since they have only realized the selﬂessness of persons,
but not have destroyed the rest part of emotional obscurations
448:
and cognitive obscurations, which are caused by the grasping
at a personal ego (self of the individual) and the grasping at
449:
phenomena as truly existent (self of phenomena) respectively. So
the other shore is the shore beyond all extremes where supreme
450: and perfect wisdom will awaken us.
452: It is well known that Prajnaparamita, the perfection of wisdom,
453: divides into four kinds: (1) the textual perfection of wisdom, namely
454: the textual Prajnaparamita, such as the long, the middle, and the
455: short Prajnaparamita sutras; (2) the foundational Prajnaparamita,
456: or the natural Prajnaparamita, which is emptiness, the foundation
457: of all things; (3) the path Prajnaparamita, that is, the ﬁve paths, the
458: path of accumulation, the path of joining, the path of seeing, the
459:
path of meditation, and the path of no-more-learning; and (4) the
resultant Prajnaparamita, the wisdom of the Buddha.
460:
32
The four types of Prajnaparamita can also divide into expressing
461:
wisdom  Prajnaparamita and expressed Prajnaparamita. The ex-
pressed Prajnaparamita is of three kinds, namely foundational or
462: natural Prajnaparamita, path Prajnaparamita, and resultant Prajna-
463: paramita. The entity of all phenomena that is beyond conceptual
464: elaboration is foundational Prajnaparamita. The Buddha perfectly
465:
understands the truth of all phenomena that is beyond conceptual
elaboration, and this wisdom is resultant Prajnaparamita. How
466: does the Buddha realize the truth and achieve this wisdom? It is
467:
by relying on the path Prajnaparamita, which is the wisdom of the
ﬁve paths.
468: What, then, is the expressing Prajnaparamita? It is the textual Praj-
469: naparamita that superbly teaches the meaning of the perfection of
470: wisdom. The textual Prajnaparamita can also divide into (1) the tex-
471: tual Prajnaparamita of the sutras and (2) the textual Prajnaparamita
472: of the commentaries or shastras. The textual Prajnaparamita of the
473: sutras is the entire set of the Prajnaparamita sutras. The textual
474: Prajnaparamita of the commentaries includes treatises such as the
475: Entrance into the Middle Way and the Four Hundred Stanzas on the
476:
Middle Way. The Heart Sutra belongs to the category of the textual
Prajnaparamita of the sutras.
478:
Indeed, the mere term “wisdom” also has diﬀerent meanings,
including worldly wisdom, transcendental wisdom and unsur-
480: Worldly wisdom means any kind of ability of mastering a worldly
481: technique, a project, or a discipline. As worldly people put it, it
482:
is to be clever and quick-witted and endowed with a profound
erudition. In evaluating things by worldly standards, we can say
483: that worldly sages such as literati, scientists, and physicists possess
484: certain wisdom. However, from a transcendental perspective, that
485: is, from the perspective of transcendental wisdom, they cannot be
486: regarded as sages, since worldly wisdom is not ultimate. Worldly
487:
people have four distortions: (1) seeing what is impermanent as
permanent; (2) seeing what is suﬀering as happiness; (3) seeing
488:
what lacks a self as having a self; (4) seeing what is impure as
pure.
489:
Transcendental wisdom indicates the wisdom of the enlightened
beings such as hearers and bodhisattvas, those who understand
490: the four Dharma seals: (1) all that is conditioned is impermanent;
491:
(2) anything in cyclic existence is suﬀering; (3) all phenomena are
empty and devoid of self; and (4) nirvana is peace.
492:
34
Unsurpassable wisdom is the wisdom of the Buddha. Because the
493: Buddha has perfectly realized the selﬂessness of persons and the
494: selﬂessness of phenomena, he has perfectly understood the reality
495:
of all things. The perfection of wisdom in the Heart Sutra indicates
this unsurpassable wisdom, so it is called Prajnaparamita.
497: Hridaya means the heart, in this case signifying essence or core. The
498: quintessence of the Buddha’s teaching in its entirety is condensed
499:
in the Heart Sutra. According to historical records, in more than
forty years during which Buddha Shakyamuni turned the wheel
500: of the teaching, he taught the emptiness of the prajnaparamita for
501: about twenty-two years. The Heart Sutra contains the quintessence
502: of the teachings that the Buddha dispensed in those twenty-two
503: years. This sutra lies at the heart of all these teachings. Therefore,
504: among the vast corpus of the prajnaparamita sutras, this text is the
505:
pith, a concise presentation of the teachings elaborated upon in
the rest of the prajnaparamita sutras.
506: Hridaya also refers to the distilled, essential message of this teaching
507: itself, called the view. It is the view of the perfection of wisdom,
508:
pretty simple and direct, and recognizing the pure essence of
emptiness.
510:
The Sanskrit term sutra literally means a chain, a thread, or a
continuum. Here it means something that was heard from some-
511: one else and usually connotes a discourse. In Buddhism, it has
512: many classiﬁcations. For example, one classiﬁcation refers to the
513:
scriptures authorized by the Buddha, another to the scriptures
empowered by the Buddha, yet another to the scriptures spoken by
514: the Buddha in person, and so on. The main contents of the Heart
515: Sutra are classiﬁed under the scriptures empowered by the Buddha,
516:
for the Buddha, while absorbed in the concentration called the
apprehension of the profound, spoke this sutra by empowering
518: Setting aside the instructions taught personally by the Buddha, the
519: instructions spoken by certain special ﬁgures can also be called
520: sutra. For example, although the Platform Sutra, highly esteemed
521: in the Chan tradition, is not a scripture spoken by the Buddha,
522: its contents diﬀer in no respect from those of a genuine scripture,
523: thereby later generations also called it sutra. However, according
524:
to rule in Tibetan Buddhism, only the contents personally spoken,
empowered, or authorized by the Buddha can be called sutra.
525: The foregoing explains the title of the Heart Sutra. As practitioners,
526: we’d better study this scripture carefully and thoroughly, chanting
527:
36
it and memorizing it in our daily practice. In this way, we will be
528: able to destroy any adverse condition or obstacle that arises in our
529: practice. In terms of its otherworldly qualities, the signiﬁcance and
530: the merit of the recitation of the Heart Sutra are quite remarkable
531: because it gathers the essentials of emptiness into a single core.
532: Certainly, we must not expect to attain enlightenment all at once,
533: and to achieve perfect understanding in one or two days of re-
534: ﬂection. Still, if we engage listening, reﬂection, and meditation in
535:
a consistent way, ignorance and aﬄictions will get weaker and
weaker in our mental continuum, while at the same time wisdom
536: will get stronger and stronger. For the time being, we will be unable
537: to soar freely in the vast space of the true reality of emptiness, yet
538: in terms of view we should be able to eliminate all kinds of doubts
539:
and mistakes through leaning and reﬂecting, and set up a brand
new and correct view. It is evident how education in Buddhism
540:
is a form of education to wisdom. Certain types of reasoning
might be diﬃcult to accept at the very beginning. Yet only through
541:
systematic reﬂection and discussion can we thoroughly eliminate
doubt and eventually bring wisdom to perfection.
542:
37
Six Perfection


A1. The Origin of the Teaching
B1. Six Perfections
543:
Thus have I heard, at one time, the Exalted One was residing
   on Vulture Mountain in Rajgriha, together with an assembly
544: of great monks and bodhisattvas, the great beings.
546: This statement “Thus have I heard” is the opening of all Buddhist
547: sutras. Prior to entering ﬁnal nirvana, as he replied to Ananda’s
548: questions, Buddha Shakyamuni established this custom: when the
549: Buddha’s instructions are compiled into textual form as scriptures
550:
it is necessary to add this statement. The goal is to warn the
compiler that it is necessary to record the scriptures from an
551: objective standpoint, without making changes according to one’s
552: own ideas and through one’s own initiative. With this statement,
554:
it is helpful for later generations to develop sincere faith towards
the Buddhist sutras.
555:
The term “thus” expresses the perfection of the teaching. At the
setting of the teaching, Buddha Shakyamuni empowered Aval-
556: okiteshvara to speak the main contents of the Heart Sutra, and so
557: all the contents expressed in the sutra are entirely the Buddha’s
558: word. “Thus”, I have recorded the scripture truthfully, coherently
559:
and unmistakenly, just as the Buddha has spoken, without adding
or removing anything.
560:
The word “I” refers to the compiler, the bodhisattva Vajrapani. As
is well known, Buddha Shakyamuni turned the second Dharma
561:
Wheel at Vulture Peak, later compiled into scriptures by ten thou-
sand bodhisattvas including Manjushri and Maitreya. Among
562: these bodhisattvas, Vajrapani was the main compiler of the Prajna-
563: paramita sutras. It is just like the written summary of a worldly
564:
meeting, with the following statement: “Such and such is what I
have heard during the meeting.” Hence, “Thus have I heard” are
565: the words spoken by the compiler, the bodhisattva Vajrapani.
566:
The term “heard” can be interpreted in two ways. Certain com-
mentators believe it means that one has merely heard but not
567: understood, for the meaning of emptiness taught by the Buddha is
568: hard to grasp. For this reason, Vajrapani would have meant: “I have
569:
39
merely heard the Buddha’s teaching simply on a literal level, but I
570: have not yet understood the subject matter.” However, Taranata of
571: the Jonang tradition regarded this interpretation to be untenable.
572: It is not certain that, at the time of hearing, Vajrapani would have
573:
completely lacked any understanding of the subject matter. It is
also a possibility that he had a partial understanding.
574:
[...] at one time, the Exalted One was residing on Vulture Moun-
tain in Rajgriha, [...]
575:
“At one time” means during one time. But why, here, is not
a speciﬁc time mentioned? Because the Buddha’s miraculous
576: transformations are countless. In front of diﬀerent living beings, at
577: times the Buddha manifests to teach as if it were summer, while
578: at other times he manifests to teach as if it were winter. This is
579: also the reason that there are so many diﬀerent interpretations in
580:
diﬀerent historical records concerning the time of the Buddha’s
passing into ﬁnal nirvana.
581: If the Buddha were a common being, then it could have been said,
582: “During a certain year, in a certain month, and in a certain day,
583: and at this hour and minute and second, while staying at a certain
584: teaching hall, he began to give a certain teaching.” Hence it would
585: have been possible to express a speciﬁc time with a degree of
586:
40
certainty. But here, from a wider perspective, the meaning is: “At
587: one time, when causes and conditions were ripe.”
588:
“The Exalted One” is Bhagavat in Sanskrit. The meaning is “En-
dowed with Transcendence, Ownership, and Destruction”. Tran-
589:
scendence means “reaching beyond the extremes of samsara and
nirvana”. Ownership means “possessing the merits of the six
590:
paramitas”. Destruction means “eliminating the four types of
mara”, that is, defeating the mara of the aggregates, the mara
591:
of aﬄictions, the mara of death, and the deity Mara. Only the
Buddha is perfectly endowed with the qualities of “Transcendence,
593:
“was residing on Vulture Mountain in Rajgriha”: The Buddha
was staying on Vulture Mountain nearby the city of Rajgriha.
594: Rajgriha, the capital of the ancient state of Magadha, was one of
595: the great cities in India back to that time. There are about eighteen
596: kilometers between Rajgriha and the Nalanda monastic university.
597:
The Buddha stayed in Rajgriha for rather long periods. And during
these periods, Ananda, Mahakasyapa, and Mahamaudgalyayana,
598: took refuge in the Buddha right there in Rajgriha.
599: Vulture Mountain is one of the main sites where the Buddha turned
600:
the second wheel of the teaching. As he once approached Vulture
Mountain, Tsangyang Gyatso, the renowned Sixth Dalai Lama,
601:
41
then perceived the Prajnaparamita sutras all over the mountain,
602:
and so he dared not climb on top. In 1990, when His Holiness
Jigme Phuntsok Rinpoche approached Vulture Mountain, he said,
603: “Back then, Tsangyang Gyatso dared not climb the mountain, but
604: this time we must go.” So the people then followed His Holiness to
605:
climb the mountain. As they reached the top, they paid homage to
the platform where the Buddha turned the Wheel of the Dharma,
606:
to the caves of Mahakasyapa and Mahamaudgalyayana, as well as
to the other holy sites at the very top.
607:
[...] together with an assembly of great monks and bodhisattvas,
the great beings.
608: At that time, the retinue of followers who received the teachings
609:
was made of “an assembly of great monks” for the common vehicle,
and of “bodhisattvas, the great beings” for the Mahayana.
610:
According to some commentators, the expression “great monks”
does not refer to common monks, but to those monks who have
611: attained the resultant state of arhat; and the expression “bod-
612:
hisattvas, the great beings” refers here to the bodhisattvas who
have realized the ultimate truth. Common bodhisattvas—the bod-
613:
hisattvas who have merely generated the conventional aspiration
to awakening, as well as certain monks who have received the
614:
42
common monastic vows, are not the actual retinue to whom the
615: Buddha is imparting the teaching here.
616:
For the term of bodhisattva, bodhi means “enlightened, awak-
ened”, freed from the obscurations of dualistic and conceptual
617: thinking. Sattva means “courageous being”. The enlightened be-
618: ings, the bodhisattvas, must be courageous because they no longer
619:
exist merely for themselves and their family and friends. They
dedicate the entire activities of this body, speech and mind to
620:
bringing joy and happiness to all sentient beings as limitless in
number as space itself.
621: Arhat is a Sanskrit word meaning “one who subdues or destroys
622: enemies”. This does not refer to an external, physically existent
623: enemy, but rather is a metaphor referring to the inner enemies of
624:
ego-clinging, the emotions, and their concomitant obscurations.
An arhat has completely uprooted these enemies.
625:
“Together with” means to be complete together. The aim of this
multitude of monks and bodhisattvas altogether is to meet the
626: Buddha, attain enlightenment, and beneﬁt living beings.
627: Thus, the foregoing text included in the prologue conveys the six
628: kinds of perfections: “Thus” is the perfection of the teaching; “I
629: have heard” is the perfection of the compiler; “at one time” is
630: the perfection of time; “the Exalted One” is the perfection of the
631:
43
root teacher; “was residing on Vulture Mountain in Rajgriha” is
632: the perfection of the setting; “together with an assembly of great
633:
monks and bodhisattvas, the great beings” is the perfection of
retinue.
634: In general, most scriptures include these six types of perfections.
635: It is just like the written summary of a worldly meeting, where
636: certain key elements such as the time, the location, the host, the
637:
participating members, the rapporteur, and the meeting outline,
are all indicated.
639: B2. The Background to the Occurrence
640:
At that time, the Exalted One was absorbed in a concentra-
   tion on the discernment of things called the “apprehension
642:
Also, at that time, Avalokiteshvara, the bodhisattva, the
   great being, as he engaged the profound perfection of wis-
643:
dom, clearly perceived that the ﬁve aggregates are empty of
   inherent existence.
644: When all conditions including the time, the root teacher, the retinue,
645: and the teaching, were present, the Exalted One entered into a
646:
deep concentration, that is, he entered into a meditative absorption
called the “apprehension of the profound”.
647:
45
Why is it called profound? Because ordinary arhats, common be-
648: ings, and non-Buddhists, are fundamentally unable to apprehend
649: the reality of all things, which is beyond all conceptual elabora-
650:
tions. This realm of reality is unfathomable, and so it is called
profound.
651: Apprehension: This profound realm is perceived clearly and com-
652:
pletely by the Buddha’s individual apprehension, therefore this
type of absorption is said to be profound and luminous.
653:
The expression discernment of things refers to many diﬀerent
kinds of elements, such as the ﬁve aggregates, the twelve sense
654: bases, and the eighteen constituents, which, on the ultimate level,
655:
are beyond all conceptual elaborations, while manifest like dreams
and illusions on the relative level.
656: We should understand that the state of a buddha has no distinctions
657: between absorbing into or emerging from a concentration. Here,
658: by saying that the Buddha absorbed into a concentration, it means
659:
that in front of the ordinary beings, the Buddha’s material body
seemed to absorb into, and emerge from concentration.
660:
Also, at that time [...]

As the entire retinue was on site, the Buddha had already absorbed
into the profound concentration.
661:
46
Avalokiteshvara, the bodhisattva, the great being, [...]
662: These three terms refer to the great bodhisattva Avalokiteshvara. In
663: Chandrakirti’s Entrance into the Middle Way, the term bodhisattva
664: is explained as follows: only the beings who have attained the ﬁrst
665: bodhisattva level and above can be called bodhisattvas. The term
666: great being, mahasattva in Sanskrit, refers to the great bodhisattvas.
667:
In general, only the bodhisattvas who abide on the three pure
levels (that is, the eighth, the ninth, and the tenth bodhisattva
668: level) can be called great bodhisattvas. But why are they called
669: “great”? It is because the bodhisattvas who abide on these three
670: levels possess extensive compassion, wisdom, and power, and they
671:
can engage the vast teachings of the Mahayana, since they are able
to conquer all kinds of demons.
672: [...] as he engaged the profound perfection of wisdom, [...]
673: This statement illustrates how, amid the entire retinue, the bod-
674: hisattva Avalokiteshvara practiced the perfection of wisdom. The
675: term engage has several meanings. Generally speaking, activities
676:
such as reading or listening to the perfection of wisdom are all
forms of engaging the perfection of wisdom. Here it means that
677:
when the Buddha entered into the deep concentration, the bod-
hisattva Avalokiteshvara also absorbed into his meditation on the
678: perfection of wisdom, inspired by the power of the Buddha.
680:
[...] clearly perceived that the ﬁve aggregates are empty of inherent
existence.
681: At this time, Avalokiteshvara clearly perceived that the ﬁve aggre-
682:
gates are entirely empty of inherent existence. All compounded
things or phenomena are encapsulated among the ﬁve aggregates.
683: The term “ﬁve aggregates” means the gathering together of form,
684: feelings, perceptions, mental formations, and consciousness, which
685: conceals the true nature of things. The ﬁrst of the ﬁve aggregates
686:
is the aggregate of forms, followed in turn by the aggregate of
feelings, the aggregate of perceptions, the aggregate of mental
687: formations, and the aggregate of consciousness.
688: The meaning of this statement is that the bodhisattva Avalokitesh-
689: vara saw with the utmost clarity that all compounded things are
690:
empty of inherent existence. The expression “clearly perceive” has
diﬀerent meanings:
691: For ordinary beings, clear perception is to observe through the
692: modes of generally characterized and of self-characterized objects.
693:
For example, we can engage observation of the statement “the
ﬁve aggregates are empty” by means of analytical reasoning.
694: Thus, it is by means of conceptual discrimination that we come to
695:
observe with clarity that the ﬁve aggregates are empty of inherent
existence.
696:
48
For hearers and solitary buddhas, clear perception is the under-
697: standing that the ﬁve aggregates are the principal and secondary
698:
causes of suﬀering, and that the ﬁve aggregates are both suﬀer-
ing and its origin. Hence, by means of the reasoning concerning
699:
the selﬂessness of a person, they clearly perceive that the ﬁve
aggregates are empty of inherent existence.
700: For buddhas and bodhisattvas, clear perception is the consummate
701:
perception of the ﬁve aggregates as empty of inherent existence
through the mode of both the selﬂessness of a thing and the
702:
selﬂessness of a person. Hence, the degree to which they perceive
the emptiness of the ﬁve aggregates is the most perfected.
703: The phrase beyond all suﬀering is lacking in the Tibetan trans-
704: lation, while several Chinese translations including Xuanzang’s
705: translation have this statement. So it’s better for us to know this and
706: have a brief explanation of it. The literal meaning of this statement
707: is “transcending, surpassing all suﬀering”. According to the Ab-
708: hidharmakosa, suﬀering divides into three types: (1) suﬀering upon
709: suﬀering, (2) suﬀering of change, and (3) all-pervasive suﬀering of
710: conditioning. By absorbing into the meditation on the perfection
711:
of wisdom, the bodhisattva Avalokiteshvara transcends all kinds
of suﬀering. This is exactly the power of Prajnaparamita.
712:
49
Summary: The Buddha’s Silence and the Main
Figures
713: Thus, in the foregoing we have explained the opening portion of
714: this sutra, namely the causes and conditions by which the Heart
715: Sura came about. Here, the most important of these is the Buddha’s
716: absorption into meditation. If the Buddha had not absorbed into
717:
meditation, Avalokiteshvara would have been unable to absorb into
his meditation on wisdom, and Shariputra would have also been
718: unable to ask his question. According to several great commentaries
719: of ancient India, the main conditions that brought about the Heart
720: Sutra were: (1) the power of the Buddha’s meditative absorption;
721:
and (2) the fact that Avalokiteshvara engaged the prajnaparamita
through the Buddha’s empowerment, and that, as a result, he
722: clearly perceived that the ﬁve aggregates are empty.
723: Generally speaking, there are said to be three principal kinds of
724:
scriptures attributed to the Buddha: those words that are actually
spoken by the Buddha himself, those words spoken by a bod-
725:
hisattva or a disciple on behalf of the Buddha, and those words
spoken by disciples or bodhisattvas that were directly inspired
726: by the Buddha. While this preliminary section of the Heart Sutra
727: pertaining to the context of the origin of its teaching belongs to
728:
the second category, the main body of the text belongs to the third
category.
729:
50
Some might then ask, why Avalokiteshvara is the main ﬁgure in the
730:
Buddha’s retinue? According to some commentators, Avalokitesh-
vara was at that time the main person in charge of the assembly,
731: thereby Shariputra addressed his question to him.
732:
According to another interpretation, because the subject matter
of this scripture is compassion and emptiness, by means of his
733:
miraculous powers the Buddha clearly perceived that, if spoken
by Avalokiteshvara, the teaching would have brought beneﬁt to
734:
endless living beings. Therefore, the Buddha would have inten-
tionally empowered Avalokiteshvara to engage the perfection
735:
of wisdom, and to clearly perceive that the ﬁve aggregates are
emptiness. Likewise, having received the Buddha’s empowerment,
736:
Shariputra would have thus intentionally raised the question to
Avalokiteshvara.
737: From this, we see that there are three main ﬁgures in the Heart Sutra,
738: and that the Buddha is the most important of them. In the whole
739: interaction, ultimately the Buddha says only one sentence, and all
740: the other contents, including the foundation, path, and resulting
741: state as a whole, are entirely taught in Shariputra’s question and in
742: Avalokiteshvara’s answer. Regardless, it is the Buddha who asks all
743:
questions as he empowers Shariputra, and who speaks all teachings
while absorbed in meditation as he empowers Avalokiteshvara.
745:
A2. Main Text
B1. The Question and the Answer
C1. Bring up the Question
746:
Then, the venerable Shariputra, by the power of the Bud-
   dha, said to the bodhisattva, the great being, the noble Aval-
747:
okiteshvara, “If a son or daughter of noble qualities wishes
   to practice the profound perfection of wisdom, how should
749: When the Buddha absorbed into meditation, Shariputra was there
750: on the setting of the teaching. By the force of the Buddha’s mighty
751:
miraculous powers, Shariputra then stood up, joined the palms
of his hands, and respectfully addressed the bodhisattva Aval-
752: okiteshvara, saying, “If a son of noble qualities wishes to practice
753:
the profound perfection of wisdom, how should he then practice
it?”
754:
53
Then: In that very moment. Right then, the entire retinue was
755:
at the setting of the teachings and the Buddha absorbed into his
profound samadhi. It is the very moment when, empowered by
756: the Buddha, the bodhisattva Avalokiteshvara also practiced the
757:
perfection of wisdom, and clearly perceived that the ﬁve aggregates
are empty.
758: If Avalokiteshvara had not clearly perceived that the ﬁve aggregates
759: are empty, he would have had no reason to explain to Shariputra
760: what he then saw. Therefore, we should be aware of the importance
761: of our own practice or realization of the Dharma teachings. Based
762: on listening and reﬂecting, we have to take the ﬁnal step of prac-
763:
ticing, and only through practicing and meditating by ourselves,
can we really absorb the teaching into our own mind stream and
764: achieve the corresponding realization on our own.
765:
The venerable Shariputra
                       : Venerable, or ayus.mat in Sanskrit, is an
766: honoriﬁc form of address. It is just like the forms of address that
767: we use when we often say “great abbot”, “eminent”, or “elder”.
768: Here the name Shariputra refers to one of the Buddha’s ten great
769:
disciples, who manifested as an arhat. Following the Indian custom,
because the name of Shariputra’s mother was Sari, based on
770:
his mother’s name he was in turn named “son of Sari”, that is,
Shariputra.
771:
54
In this sutra, it is Shariputra who addresses questions to Aval-
772: okiteshvara. No ordinary being is capable of asking questions of
773: this kind. In his appearance, Shariputra is an arhat, yet according
774:
to several commentators he is actually a bodhisattva. His wisdom
is the foremost among all of the Buddha’s disciples.
775: Because the Heart Sutra is the condensed version of the Prajna-
776: paramita sutras, prajna is its subject matter, therefore it is meant to
777: develop the practitioners’ wisdom. In this view, it was exclusively
778: congruous with the main point of the scripture to have Shariputra,
779: the foremost in wisdom, step to the fore. This is just like many
780:
other scriptures, such as the Diamond Sutra, in which among all
disciples, the Buddha addresses Subhuti, the “foremost in the
781: understanding of emptiness”. In the case of the Heart Sutra, if one
782:
did not possess certain level of wisdom, it was impossible to raise
profound questions concerning emptiness.
783:
By the power of the Buddha: Even as the foremost of the arhats,
he would still need the Buddha’s empowerment, in order to be
784: able to ask the profound questions about emptiness. Otherwise, it
785:
would be relatively hard for anyone to ask even a single, profound
question about emptiness.
786: Son or daughter of noble qualities: Literally it means sons or
787: daughters of the lineage, or of the family, which in general, can
788:
55
be understood to mean someone who has awakened to his or her
789: buddha nature, the innate potential for enlightenment. In this
790: sutra, this terms particularly refers to practitioners who have deep
791: admiration for the spiritual practices as embodied in the six per-
792: fections, and whose mind is gripped by the powerful compassion
793: that aspires to liberate all sentient beings from suﬀering. Or to
794:
put it simply, it refers to an individual whose spiritual inclination
toward the bodhisattva path has been awakened.
795: In sum, the general meaning of this passage is that, at that time,
796:
by the power of the Buddha, Shariputra asked the bodhisattva
Avalokiteshvara a question: “There are many beings in the world
797: who wish to practice the perfection of wisdom, but they ﬁnd it
798: diﬃcult, and so, if a son or a daughter of noble qualities genuinely
799: wishes to practice the Prajnaparamita, and to train in the emptiness
800:
of the Prajnaparamita, how should he or she practice, how should
he or she train?”
802:
C2. Answer the Question
D1. A Brief Instruction on How to Practice Prajnaparamita
803:
As these words were spoken, Avalokiteshvara, the bodhi-
   sattva, the great being, replied to the venerable Shariputra,
804:
saying, “If a son or a daughter of noble qualities wishes to
   train in the practice of the profound perfection of wisdom,
805:
he or she should observe that the ﬁve aggregates are empty
   of inherent existence in this way.
806: By the power of the Buddha, the bodhisattva Avalokiteshvara then
807:
provided an answer to this question. In this world, if there are
sons or daughters of noble qualities, who wish to practice the
808:
profound Prajnaparamita, they should contemplate it by way of
the ﬁve aggregates being empty.
809: In certain scriptures of deﬁnitive teaching, it is asserted that,
810: although Avalokiteshvara has become a buddha a long time ago,
811:
57
abiding in countless worlds with the appearance of a buddha
812:
to help living beings, he just appears by the side of Buddha
Shakyamuni as a bodhisattva for the sake of living beings.
813: The receptacle world, and the world of sentient beings are both
814: collected in the ﬁve aggregates. Similarly, the twelve faculties, the
815: eighteen constituents, the twelve links of dependent origination,
816:
can be all summarized by the ﬁve aggregates. Therefore, the ﬁve
aggregates contain everything.
817: Here the sutra tells us that, regardless of whether one practices
818: the six perfections, or any other teaching, one should practice by
819: way of contemplating the emptiness of inherent existence. In other
820: words, one should reﬂect as follows: in ultimate truth, everything
821: is beyond all conceptual elaborations, and beyond all linguistic
822: distinctions; whereas in relative truth, everything is like an illusion,
823:
a dream, a bubble, a shadow. This is the fundamental way to
contemplate the emptiness of inherent existence.
824:
In his commentary on the Fundamental Verses on the Middle Way,
Ju Mipham Rinpoche says, “The method to contemplate the Pra-
825:
jnaparamita is, in ultimate truth, to practice by way of taking
everything as empty space, beyond all grasping, and beyond
826: all conceptual elaborations; and, in relative truth, to practice by
827:
58
way of taking everything as both appearing and lacking inherent
828:
existence.”
The Practice of the   Heart Sutra
829: Why did the Buddha manifest himself in meditative absorption in
830: order to teach this sutra? We can say that the Buddha’s implication
831:
here is to point out that we must contemplate on the Prajna-
paramita’s teaching on emptiness. Lacking such contemplation, we
832: will be unable to attain any realization.
833: The meditation practice of the Heart Sutra is extremely important.
834: But if we do not understand it, the whole thing will only amount
835: to a daily memorization of the Heart Sutra. It will be a mere verbal
836: recitation, and its actual eﬃcacy will not be as great as we should
837:
expect. Therefore, when we engage recitation, we must also engage
reﬂection and we must put the teaching into practice.
838: As Khenpo Sodargye said in his teaching, the Heart Sutra’s teaching
839:
on emptiness is extremely rare to meet during millions of cosmic
ages and we are indeed lucky to have met with this teaching.
840: Therefore, we should leave everything else to the side as much as
841:
we can, and try to ﬁnd more time to contemplate on the sutra’s
contents.
842:
59
So in brief, everyone should practice the Prajnaparamita, no matter
843: if one is a son or a daughter of noble qualities. But how do we
844: practice? It is by holding the view that the ﬁve aggregates are empty.
845: As for us ordinary beings, we apprehend that the ﬁve aggregates
846: including forms, feelings, perceptions, etc., are empty of inherent
847:
existence by means of conceptual thought; after we realize the
selﬂessness of persons and the selﬂessness of phenomena, we then
848:
clearly perceive that the ﬁve aggregates are empty by means of the
actual realization of the two selﬂessnesses.
849:
Indeed, it should be within our reach, as ordinary beings, to
hold our practice by means of the view that the ﬁve aggregates
850: are empty. For example, when we perform prostrations or recite
851: mantras, we should understand that, in relative truth, such illusory
852: and dream-like forms of merit accumulation are really existent and
853: indispensable; and in ultimate truth, however, they are beyond
854:
conceptual elaboration, just like empty space, which is immaculate
and undeﬁled.
855: If we engage practice with this view, we will gradually let go of
856: the grasping to the ﬁve aggregates, in which we so often become
857: involved in daily life. Eventually, we will be able to thoroughly
858: eliminate our conception of a self. And if we eliminate our concep-
859: tion of a self, the grasping to the ﬁve aggregates linked with the
861:
conception of a self will dissolve naturally. To practice in this way
is the fundamental practice of the Heart Sutra.
863: D2. An Extensive Elaboration on Prajnaparamita
864: In this part, we will comment extensively on the themes of the
865: Prajnaparamita from the three aspects, which are the foundational
866:
Prajnaparamita, the path Prajnaparamita, and the resultant Pra-
jnaparamita. We can include all things among the categories of
867: foundation, path, and result. In practice, we should ﬁrst ascertain
868: the foundation of all things; next, the engagement of this founda-
869: tion is the practice of the path; and further, as the path is crossed,
870: we ﬁnally reach the culminating position, and this is the result.
871: Indeed, when we explain the Great Perfection, the Mahamudra, or
872: just the essential points of the Sutrayana, we always do so from the
873: perspective of the foundation, the path, and the result. It is quite
874:
important for practitioners to establish and to gain knowledge of
the foundation, the path, and the result.
875:
62
In this part, Avalokiteshvara ﬁrst discusses the emptiness of the
876: foundation elements, such as the ﬁve aggregates, the twelve sense
877: bases, and the eighteen constituents. He then discusses the empti-
878:
ness of the path elements, such the twelve links of dependent
origination, and the four noble truths. Finally, moving on to the
879:
elements of the result, he elucidates the emptiness of the Buddha’s
wisdom.
The Five Aggregates
880: Because we are seeking to perceive both the appearances of ﬁve
881: aggregates and their emptiness, it is important to understand what
882:
the ﬁve aggregates are and how they are empty. This is one of the
Heart Sutra’s main points.
883:
According to Abhidharmakosha, whatever exists in this phenomenal
world can be condensed into two groups: compounded things
884:
and uncompounded things. Nothing whatsoever falls outside
these two categories. The ﬁve aggregates belong to the category of
885: compounded things, and in fact include them all.
886: Aggregate is called skandha in Sanskrit, means that many things
887: piled together, not just a single and independent thing. The ﬁve
888:
aggregates are the aggregate of forms, feelings, perceptions, mental
formations and consciousness.
890: Forms include the ﬁve sense faculties and their objects, as well
891:
as a slightly more problematic category called invisible form, or
invisible materiality, which we won’t go into here.
892: The sense faculties are not the ordinary sense organs, such as our
893: eyes and ears and so on, but subtle forms within the sense organs.
894:
They have particular shapes which are described very precisely in
Abhidharma.
895: The objects of the eyes, visual forms, means the various colors and
896:
shapes that appear to our eyes. They may be pleasant, unpleasant
or neutral.
897:
The objects of the ears, sounds, may occur naturally or be man-
made, or a combination of the two. A lot of sounds are just
898:
meaningless noise, but some impart meaning, for example, the
sublime, liberating message of the Dharma. As with sights, sounds
899: can be pleasant, unpleasant or neutral.
900:
The objects of the noses, smells or odors can be natural or artiﬁcial,
and once again, pleasant, unpleasant or neutral.
901: The objects of the tongues, tastes are said to be of six kinds, roughly
902: translated as sweet, sour, bitter, hot, astringent and pungent.
903:
64
The objects of the bodies, textures, or tactile sensations, may be
904: felt on the body’s surface or in its interior. Interior textures include
905:
hunger and thirst, and the feelings that come with being ill or
deeply relaxed.
906: So generally, the aggregate of forms includes all that we can see,
907:
hear, smell, taste and touch, and also the subtle faculties that do
the seeing, hearing, smelling, tasting and touching.
909:
Here feelings do not mean emotional feelings, but something
more like sensations. There are the painful, pleasant and neutral
910: sensations in the body and the pleasant, unpleasant and neutral
911: sensations in the mind. Feelings are important because they are the
912: basis for desire and aversion. We like to have happy, pleasurable
913:
feelings, and we reject feelings of sadness. So it conditions our
mental states and determines what we experience in the end.
915: Perception means the apprehension of a speciﬁc object, as circum-
916: scribed and distinct from something else. It is deﬁned as “that
917: which grasps or identiﬁes characteristics”. Perception could be non-
918:
conceptual, in the case of the ﬁve physical senses, or conceptual,
as in the perception of thoughts and ideas.
919:
65
The ﬁve non-conceptual sense perceptions are regarded as dis-
920: cerning when they are operating normally and perceiving their
921: proper objects: colors & shapes, sounds, smells, tastes and textures.
922:
Mental perception is said to be discerning when it distinguishes
identities or names. This happens when (a) mind recognizes an
923:
object and associates it with its name, and (b) the mind knows
what is referred to when a name is given.
925: It basically refers to thoughts and emotions, or what are technically
926: referred to as the mental states. Although there are many possible
927:
mental states, the Abhidharma teachings speak of ﬁfty-one, which
are held to be particularly important.
928: Sensation and perception are actually included in these ﬁfty-one
929:
mental states, but are treated separately in the list of the ﬁve
aggregates because they are especially noticeable.
931: According to the Mind-Only school, there are eight types of con-
932: sciousness. The ﬁrst ﬁve types are the consciousness of the ﬁve
933: senses (seeing, hearing, smelling, tasting, and touching), which are
934: non-conceptual, and the sixth one is the consciousness of mental
935:
66
objects, like thoughts, ideas and emotions. The seventh is the de-
936:
ﬁled mental consciousness and the eighth is alaya consciousness,
or all-ground consciousness.
937: The deﬁled mental consciousness is closely connected with the ego
938: and is where the notion of “I” and “mine” enters into experience.
939:
It is absent in the meditation of noble beings, but never ceases in
the mind stream of an ordinary being.
940: The alaya consciousness is described as a storehouse, in which
941:
we keep all our habits and instincts, the imprints or seeds of our
actions which will ripen into future experiences.
942:
To summarize, the ﬁve aggregates of form, feeling, perception,
mental formations and consciousness are compounded and inter-
943:
dependent things. None of them is a solid or single entity, but
is rather a combination of many things. We never exist for one
944: moment outside of these ﬁve aggregates. They are the foundation
