945: of samsara, the enablers of our clinging and attachment. They are
946: also, however, the key to our enlightenment, for it is only by our
947: understanding of them, by our gaining a clear picture of what they
948:
are and how they function, enlightenment can become present in
our mind stream.
949:
67
E1. The Natural Prajnaparamita
F1. The Emptiness of Five Aggregates
951:
Form is emptiness; emptiness is form. Form is not other than
   emptiness; emptiness is not other than form.
952: These four sentences teach the emptiness of the ﬁve aggregates,
953: which can be regarded as the heart of the Heart Sutra. The meaning
954:
of this passage is that material forms are emptiness, and that
emptiness is material forms; there are no material forms beyond
955: emptiness, and there is no emptiness beyond material forms. This
956: is the Heart Sutra’s main point and its essence. If we can gain a
957: genuine understanding of the non-duality of form and emptiness,
958: then the other themes of the Heart Sutra, such as the remaining four
959: aggregates, the twelve sense bases, the eighteen constituents, the
960:
twelve links of dependent origination, and the four noble truths,
can be ascertained by the same method.
961: Beginners always feel perplexed in this regard, for they ﬁnd this
962: perspective to be contradictory. How can the very things that I
963: myself see and feel, such as, for example, this microphone or this
964: cup, be emptiness? And how about this empty space in front of
965: me, how can it be inseparable from form? This is impossible! If my
967:
teacup is emptiness, then how can it contain tea? It is certainly not
emptiness.
968:
Those who propound this view have not understood the doctrinal
principle of emptiness in Buddhism. From beginningless time, we
969: have believed that the real world is simply the things around us
970: that we can see or feel, and emptiness are those that we cannot see
971: or feel. Yet, in reality, it is not so. If we analyze, all phenomena in
972: this world are devoid of an inherent existence, and as long as the
973: intrinsic nature of one thing is nonexistent, it is emptiness.
974:
Some might engage the following thought: “Since everything
is empty, we must not grasp to anything, we must give up on
975:
everything, and so there is nothing at all that we must do.” It
is indeed not so. The emptiness that is taught in Buddhism is
976:
the emptiness of nature and not the emptiness of characteristics.
Buddhism never denies the appearance of all phenomena. To us
977: deluded beings, the characteristics of appearance are deﬁnitely
978: existent. Appearance, however, is not separate from emptiness, and
979: emptiness is also not separate from appearance. Appearance and
980:
emptiness are both actually a single entity. This, in turn, is called
the emptiness of nature in dependent origination.
982: In the commentary on the Heart Sutra by Taranatha, the great
983: Tibetan master of the Jonang tradition, there is a simile that aptly
984: illustrates this issue. To the eyes of a person aﬀected by jaundice,
985: a white conch appears as yellow, so yellow is the color that this
986: person sees at that very moment. Yet, in truth, the white conch
987: is not yellow at all, and there is absolutely no yellow color in the
988: conch. Only to the eyes of a person aﬀected by jaundice, it appears
989: as yellow, because that person is unable to see the white conch.
990: In reality, the white color is merely the true aspect of the conch.
991:
Therefore, we can say: To those people whose eyes are damaged,
the white conch is simply yellow, and the yellow conch is simply
992:
white. The yellow conch will not be other than the white conch,
and likewise the white conch will not be other than the yellow
994:
Similarly, emptiness can be compared to the white conch, and
the yellow conch can be compared to the material things that we
995: perceive. Just like the white color is the original nature of the
996:
conch, emptiness is the real nature of all material things. The
material things that we perceive in this very moment, whether a
997: teacup, a bottle, or a pillar, all have a color, a shape, the quality of
998: obstructiveness, and exist as discrete solid appearances. In reality,
999: however, at the right moment they appear in this way, they are
1000:
70
emptiness. The perceptions of all buddhas and bodhisattvas is
1001:
such an unobstructed, great, luminous emptiness. Moreover, this
great, luminous emptiness is not separate from appearance.
1002:
The commentary on the Heart Sutra by Rongton Mawe Senge, and
the Trilogy on Rest by Longchenpa, both take the analogy of the
1003:
reﬂection of the moon in the water to refer to emptiness. The
moon in the water is emptiness, and emptiness is the moon in
1004: the water. Emptiness is not diﬀerent from the moon in the water,
1005: and the moon in the water is not diﬀerent from emptiness. In this
1006: regard, the Buddha emphasized that appearances that we perceive
1007: are actually not separate from emptiness; they are just like the
1008: reﬂection of the moon in the water, or the appearance in a dream.
1009:
From this perspective, since all phenomena are devoid of inherent
existence, we say they are emptiness.
1010: Cut the Attachment to the Four Extremes
1011: According to the doctrine of the Middle Way, we can also ascertain
1012:
this statement through the negation of the four extremes, which
are existence, non-existence, both existence and non-existence,
1013:
and neither existence nor non-existence. These four extremes are
respectively the grasping of common beings and non-Buddhists,
1014:
the grasping of hearers and solitary buddhas, and the grasping of
bodhisattvas.
1016: The reason why the text says “form is emptiness” is that ordinary
1017: beings grasp to existence, that is, we have strong attachment to
1018: material things, and regard all objects as truly existent. In this
1019: regard, what the Buddha is telling us is: “Ordinary beings believe
1020: in truly existent things such as the bottle and the pillar, while in
1021: fact these things are not separate from emptiness, so one must not
1022:
grasp to the material characteristics of external objects.” This is the
refutation of the extreme of existence.
1023: For us ordinary beings, even though we might make a great eﬀort
1024: during an entire lifetime, in the end our pains will come to nothing,
1025: and our deeds will rather follow us in our future lives, and there we
1026: will receive their reward, as we will be subjected to the suﬀerings
1027: of cyclic existence. The root cause of all these suﬀerings is our
1028: ignorance, or the lack of the knowledge that everything does not
1029: truly exist but is just a rainbow-like appearance that we can never
1030: grasp. Due to our ignorance, we have this wrong perception that
1031: everything is a solid and permanent entity, just like the person
1032: aﬀected by jaundice seeing the while conch as yellow. So once we
1033:
have this wrong perception, we develop the wrong view, and then
based on the wrong view, all our actions only become the cause
1034:
of suﬀering and aﬄictions, and in turn, the cause of the endless
journey in samsara.
1036:
The reason why the text says “emptiness is form” is that hears
and solitary buddhas regard the emptiness in the selﬂessness of
1037: persons as truly existent, or their nirvana as truly existent. Thus,
1038: they have a grasping to this emptiness. “Emptiness is form” can be
1039: employed to refute their assertion. The emptiness in the selﬂessness
1040: of persons is actually not separate from material forms, for material
1041: things are also referents for purity and luminosity. Such state of
1042: purity and luminosity is not completely nonexistent. The extreme
1043:
of nonexistence, in which hearers and solitary buddhas engage, is
thus refuted.
1044: In sum, when we see a cup, which seems to be solidly existent, the
1045: appearance of this cup is exactly emptiness. It has no true material
1046: entity. This is the meaning of “form is emptiness”. Yet, although
1047: it has no true material entity, the cup can still contain tea, for it
1048:
is not absolutely and merely empty, or the so-called nothingness.
This is the meaning of “emptiness is form”.
1049:
When the Middle Way engages analysis by the reasoning of the
vajra-splinter or by the reasoning that refutes production of the
1050: existent and of the non-existent, material forms are entirely nonex-
1051: istent, and yet it is in this very nonexistence that everything can
1052: become manifest. We should not understand these statements in
1053:
73
the wrong way that initially this cup is existent, but after having
1054: engaged analysis, it has then become empty. Indeed, it is empty at
1055:
the very moment it contains water; and it can contain water while
it is empty.
1056: “Form is emptiness” reﬂects the fundamental empty nature of all
1057:
form. “Emptiness is form” is the appreciation of interdependent
origination. From the coming together of causes and conditions
1058:
arise—from emptiness—all the beautiful forms, feelings, and per-
ceptions that we experience, which are the appearance of this
1059: phenomenal world. It is the beauty of emptiness that allows all
1060:
forms to arise, not as singular entities or things, but as the coming
together of forms.
1061: 3 Form Is Not Other than Emptiness
1062: The third and the fourth verses, “form is not other than empti-
1063: ness, emptiness is not other than form”, were spoken for certain
1064: bodhisattvas, because they still retain a subtle grasping to the
1065:
two extremes of “both existence and non-existence” and “neither
existence nor nonexistence”.
1066: Certain bodhisattvas see form and emptiness as two contrasting
1067: things. If it is form, it cannot be empty, and if it is empty, it cannot
1068: be form. Although the text says “form is emptiness, emptiness is
1069: form”, they might still feel as if these are two things that exist there
1070:
74
in a uniﬁed state, both existence and non-existence forged together
1071:
somehow. Indeed, all phenomena are fundamentally the perfectly
unobstructed non-duality of form and emptiness. Therefore, in
1072: order to refute the bodhisattva’s grasping to these two conceptions,
1073: the Buddha said, “form is not other than emptiness.” Form and
1074:
emptiness are not two separate entities. They are perfectly uniﬁed,
without the slightest duality.
1075: In the third statement, the Buddha intends to free us from the
1076: concept that there are both existence and non-existence, since it is
1077: not the ultimate level of truth, but still a level of clinging and ﬁxation
1078: to the idea that there are two diﬀerent, independent entities which
1079: are joined. In the state free from all extreme concepts, emptiness
1080: and form have always existed intimately as one. So “form is not
1081:
other than emptiness” is really presenting the logic of the union
of emptiness and appearance.
1082: 4 Emptiness Is Not Other than Form
1083:
Once having the understanding that the ideas of existence and
non-existence are faulty and extreme, we can simply know that
1084: the ideas that existence and non-existence do not exist is still an
1085:
extreme position. Therefore, the ﬁnal statement tells us that we
should transcend the grasping to the conceptions that there is
1086: neither existence not non-existence. These four statements are able
1087:
75
to subvert our ability to hold onto any position or extreme, and
1088: then we are cut loose from the cycle of dualistic concepts to rest
1089:
in the state of emptiness. Thus we know that the actual state of
emptiness is beyond all conceptual thoughts and elaborations.
1091: According to the teaching on buddha nature, we can have deeper
1092: understanding on the true reality of forms. The real forms are the
1093: forms of buddha nature, or the realm of reality. For us ordinary
1094: beings, we cannot see it, because it pertains to the realm of buddhas
1095:
and bodhisattvas. This is comparable to the white conch, which
can only be seen by individuals whose eyes are not damaged by
1096:
jaundice. Those whose eyes are damaged will not see the white
conch. All they will see is the yellow conch.
1097: However, in either case, we should be aware of that, emptiness is
1098: not mere nothingness, but the entity of the realm of reality which
1099: is luminous and free from conceptual elaboration. So the conch
1100: can also serve as an analogy for the inexpressible realm of reality.
1101: For diﬀerent individuals, it appears diﬀerently, but regardless of
1102: whether one’s eyes are or are not aﬀected, that which is seen is
1103: just a conch. Likewise, regardless of appearances, the entity of all
1104:
things is the realm of reality, which is luminous and free from
conceptual elaboration.
1105:
76
So the luminous and nonconceptual entity of the realm of reality is
1106: truly existent. But the way of existence is not established by means
1107: of the conceptual mind of us ordinary beings, such as reﬂection on
1108: shape and color, or through linguistic expression. In contrast, it
1109:
exists in a way that entirely transcends language and reﬂection, a
way that cannot be expressed.
1110:
Some may wonder, how   can everything appear in emptiness?
Indeed, this is the capability of our own buddha nature. All kinds
1111: of appearance pertain to the subtle workings of the mind, or in
1112:
other words, anything can become manifested by the subtle powers
of the mind.
1113: Ju Mipham Rinpoche’s The Lion Roar: A Commentary on the Essence of
1114: the Tathagatas and other commentaries by great masters investigated
1115: one particular question: whether exterior, insentient things, possess
1116: the essence of the tathagatas. Indeed, insentient things are but one
1117: subtle aspects of the essence of the tathagatas, because insentient
1118:
things are also one manifestation of the mind. The fundamental
nature of the mind is emptiness, and within the emptiness of the
1119:
mind, such material forms can indeed be manifested.
Non-existence from the Scientiﬁc Point of View
1120:
Anyone who has studied Physics, or who has some knowledge of
Quantum Mechanics, is aware of the following: All matter that is
1121:
77
visible to the eye is composed of molecules; molecules subdivide
1122: into atoms; atoms subdivide into electrons and the atomic nucleus;
1123: the atomic nucleus subdivides into protons and neutrons; these,
1124: then, divide into the even smaller quarks; and after quarks we still
1125:
have subquarks. Today, we know that below subquarks there is a
quantum ﬁeld.
1126: So in the theory of Quantum Mechanics, we have the convertibility
1127: of mass and energy: any matter, such as a bottle, or a pillar, is
1128: convertible into energy. In other words, everything, including the
1129:
very earth that sustains our existence, and our very ﬂesh and body,
is convertible into energy.
1130: But what is this quantum ﬁeld or energy ﬁeld? It is space-like
1131: energy that cannot be seen or touched. Put another way, all there
1132: is behind any idea concerning matter is only a ﬁeld. Beyond this
1133: ﬁeld, there is nothing real. For example, when we look at this cup,
1134: this cup is made of energy. Therefore, it does not possess a physical
1135: entity that is obstructive and real. This energy is not obtained
1136:
through conversion. Energy is simply simultaneous with material
existence.
1137:
Therefore, even when we engage analysis from the perspective
of physics, we reach the conclusion that, ultimately, whether a
1138: bottle, an atom, or a quark, anything cannot truly exist. As the
1139:
78
fundamental entity of things is nonexistent, how can things not be
1140: emptiness? This point of view is much closer to that of Buddhism.
1141: Certainly, from a Buddhist perspective, this view is not an ultimate
1142: view, because Quantum Physicists still grasp onto the real existence
1143: of a ﬁeld, and so they fall far short from a Buddhist position.
1144: Some might ask, “Scientists engaged a step-by-step analysis of
1145:
matter with scientiﬁc equipment, and then reached the conclusion
of quantum  ﬁeld. How does Buddhism  ascertain emptiness?”
1146:
We can say that the modes through which Buddhism ascertains
emptiness are quite numerous, each with its own beneﬁts. Of these,
1147: a simple method whose logic is rather similar to that of Physics is
1148: to engage analysis, as earlier in the method of Physics, of the coarse
1149:
substance of, say, a bottle. Then, when we reach down to the level
of energy, which contemporary Physics cannot analyze in more
1150:
detail, we take a step further and ascertain emptiness through
methods such as the great reasoning of dependent origination,
1151:
and the reasoning that refutes production from the existent and
from the nonexistent.
1152:
For example, take the following questions: “How is energy pro-
duced?” “Is it energy that was previously existent and that is
1153:
produced again, or is it energy that is produced and that was
previously completely nonexistent?” In the case of the former,
1154: we incur in the error of unnecessary production, since energy
1155:
79
was already existent. In the case of the latter, we ask again: “Is
1156:
this energy produced by causes and conditions, or is it produced
without a cause?”
1157: If it is produced without a cause, we incur the error of endless
1158: production. If it is produced by causes and conditions, then, because
1159: a result is produced by a cause, if the cause and result are related,
1160: then the causal element exists at the same time with the result
1161: element. And, since the result element is already existent, it is
1162: unnecessary for it to be produced again. But if cause and result
1163:
are not related, then how can the causal element have a function
in the production of the result element? Eventually, through a
1164: series of deductions, this thing we know as energy also vanishes
1165: without a trace, becoming something that it is only possible to
1166:
imagine thanks to our conceptual thoughts, but which, in reality,
is something that is completely nonexistent.
1167:
Buddhism  surpasses science also in so far as the statements of
Quantum Physics are scientiﬁc ﬁndings that common people are
1168: both unable to experiment and to infer directly. In contrast, the
1169: Buddha does not ask anyone in the world to accept the “ﬁndings”
1170: of his realization. He takes a step further. He helps ordinary beings
1171: to directly infer his conclusions on emptiness by means of logical
1172: reasonings that are accessible to all. Moreover, if one wishes to take
1173: a step further, to put the Buddha’s teaching into practice, he or she
1174:
80
can experience directly the realm of emptiness that the Buddha
1175:
himself realized.
The Illusion of the Self
1176: From the foregoing reasoning we realize that our eyes perceive the
1177:
substance of diﬀerent kinds of forms. And yet, when we track the
essence of this substance, we end up with empty hands. When we
1178: do not examine it, the bottle seems like to exist; but if we examine
1179:
it in detail, we realize that the so called bottle actually does not
exist.
1180: Again, let us take this building as an example. We believe this is a
1181: real and indivisible house. Yet in truth it is made of many kinds
1182:
of building materials. There is no essence of the house apart from
a pile of building materials. Can you recognize which, among
1183:
the broken pieces of such building materials, is the house? It is
impossible.
1184:
Many of us may think, “I am sitting here, taking a class.” But
indeed, we overlook one gap in this logic. Ultimately speaking,
1185: where is what the so called the “I”? Is it in our body, or is it outside?
1186: Most people will answer by saying: “It is certainly in my body,
1187: for it cannot be outside.” We then go on and ask: “Given that it is
1188: within your body, in what part of your body is it, is it in the head,
1189: in the torso, in the four limbs, or is in some other place?” Many of
1190:
81
us know that there are people who are deprived of the four limbs
1192: If we believe that what we call the “I” is in our brains or in our hearts,
1193: we can then further analyze the brain and the heart. Eventually,
1194: after we search for it in each part through our analysis, we will be
1195: unable to ﬁnd the place where this “I” exists. Perhaps, some will
1196:
say, even though it is impossible to ﬁnd it in any part of the body,
we still have a soul, and that will be the so called “I”.
1197: But what is this soul? Essentially, it is nothing but an idea or a
1198: concept. We can analyze such an idea or concept on account of the
1199: length of time, and again it can be analyzed down to emptiness. We
1200: can say, without exaggeration, that no matter what we regard as an
1201: “I”, the reasonings of the Middle Way can refute it completely.
1202: There is another reason that we can realize the emptiness of all
1203: things: if all things were truly existent, their entities would be ﬁxed
1204: and unchanging, yet it is not so in reality. Take, for example, sound
1205: itself. Some people will regard a sound as pleasant and melodious,
1206: whereas other will regard it as unpleasant and unreﬁned. Take a
1207: bottle of wine for example. Those who like to drink will see its
1208: coloring as translucent and penetrating, will feel as if its fragrance
1209: is aromatic and long-lasting, its ﬂavor rich and refreshing, the
1210: sound of it being poured into a glass the jingling of silver threads,
1211:
82
and the feeling of it being ingested and reaching the stomach
1212: comparable to walking among clouds. It can truthfully be called a
1213: manifold wonder for color, sound, smell, taste, and touch. But to
1214: those who are allergic to alcohol, or who do not enjoy drinking, all
1215: such sensations are basically impossible to ﬁnd, for it is spicy and
1216: pungent to smell, bitter and piercing to drink, and as soon as it gets
1217: into the stomach after ingestion it makes one sick. No matter what,
1218: there will be no wonderful feeling. If this wine was something
1219: that is truly existent, it would only possess a ﬁxed essence. Yet,
1220:
in reality, it accommodates diﬀerent opinions, for everyone has a
diﬀerent view on how he or she feels about it.
1221: These reasonings illustrate that both the “I” and external objects do
1222: not exist as real essences, and are beyond such artiﬁcial entities. It is
1223: only through their conceptual minds that people apprehend such
1224: illusions as an “I” or as external objects. The truth of emptiness
1225:
will emerge only as we get rid of these deceiving semblances by
means of the Buddhist doctrine.
Ordinary Beings’ Perceptions
1226:
We cannot decide if things are existent or nonexistent only on
the basis of our own perception, because our sense organs are
1227:
essentially mistaken. For example, if you deem something as
existent on account of your eyes being able to see it, and to be
1228:
83
simply nonexistent on account of your being unable to see it, then,
1229: what would you say of all matter that we cannot see with the
1230: naked eye, such as the X rays, the ultraviolet rays, the infrared rays,
1231: molecules, atoms, neutrons, protons, and electrons, and the very air
1232:
that we generally regard as completely empty, but which contains
particles and elements such as nitrogen and oxygen? Would you
1233: still say they are all nonexistent?
1234: Also, we normally regard a table as something that is still and
1235:
immobile. Yet, in reality, each and every atom that forms the table
is in constant ﬂux.
1236: Take, as a further example, something we dream of during sleep
1237: that we can both see and touch. In a dream, when we eat we can eat
1238: with satisfaction, when we climb a mountain we can get drenched
1239:
in sweat, when a tiger devours us we will cry out in great pain.
Still, does this mean that dream states are truly existent?
1240:
You might then say, “Dream sensations are blurry, while upon
waking perceptions are clearer; dream events are constantly and
1241: incessantly changing, with no logic, whereas real events are rather
1242:
stable, and understandable according to logic; sooner or later
people wake from dreams, while after they are awake they cannot
1244:
84
But sometimes you may have had a kind of dream where sensations
1245: are particularly clear, and the dream state is so realistic to the degree
1246: that you cannot say that you are dreaming, because you believe
1247: that everything in the dream is real. So, how can you tell whether
1248: your entire life, the life you experience during the waking state,
1249:
is not such a dream, the one that has been going on for a longer

1250: In truth, in most dreams we actually do not know we are dreaming,
1251: and we ﬁnd out it was a dream only upon waking. Likewise, could
1252: it be that we do not know that our waking life is a dream, perhaps,
1253:
only because we have not yet awakened from this great dream?
In principle, what is the real diﬀerence between dreams and the
1254:
waking state? Indeed, any time we wake up from a dream, we can
ask the same question to ourselves: “How do I determine whether
1255:
what I have just experienced was a dream, or whether what I am
now experiencing is a dream?”
1256: The fact that in a dream we might be aware of nonexistent things
1257: as existent, illustrates that our sensations are very unreliable. Thus,
1258: the self that we are aware of during the waking state, together with
1259:
the world that surrounds us, might also be an illusory perception,
a dream-like illusion.
1260:
85
That our sensations are mistaken is proven by countless facts.
1261: Everything in the universe, from the sun, the moon, and the stars,
1262: up to all plants, insects, and ﬁsh, every single thing is the mere
1263:
appearance of form, and the only truth behind the appearance of
form is emptiness.
1264: In Buddhist scriptures, there is such an example. If, on a moonless
1265: night, you light an incense stick, and if you draw a circle in the
1266: air with it, you will see a shining circle, yet we all know that in
1267: reality there is no circle such as a wheel in the air, but only a piece
1268: of incense, which was lit is now being turned around in circles.
1269: Because our eyes lack the power to distinguish it, all we see in
1270:
its place is a wheel. The Buddha called such a circle the “wheel
of spinning ﬁre”, which in reality is nonexistent. He employed
1271:
this phenomenon to characterize the appearances apprehended by
common people, which are nothing but their delusion.
1273: To be sure, the Buddha never negated conventional phenomena,
1274: for he would never say, “This cup is empty, therefore it cannot be
1275: utilized to contain tea.” These phenomena can all be established in
1276:
mistaken and illusory perception. However, these phenomena are
not unlike the images that we see in dreams. Although we can see
1277: them and touch them, they cannot stand for the real existence of
1278:
86
such dream realms. Or else, these phenomena can be likened to
1279: the moon in water. Although it appears to be like the real moon,
1280: yet in truth it is only a reﬂection, a mere mistaken perception.
1281:
Why do these phenomena exist? It is the function of dependent
origination. When causes and conditions gather together, incon-
1282: ceivable things will manifest. The truth of dependent origination
1283: is profound, and it would be somewhat hard to understand it all at
1284: once. However, if we study a few extra works in the Middle Way,
1285:
and if we engage practice according to the view explained there,
we will eventually understand its profound meaning.
1286:
It should be clear that, when we talk about emptiness, “empty”
does not refer to the empty space in and outside a bottle. This
1287:
is comparable to an actor with outstanding performing skills.
Although he or she can change all kinds of diﬀerent makeups and
1288: costumes, and he or she can play all kinds of diﬀerent roles, it
1289: will still be him or her, no matter what, for he or she will not have
1290:
changed because of a diﬀerent costume, or because of a diﬀerent
role. “Emptiness” is like this, too. Regardless of the diﬀerent
1291:
expressions of emptiness, its fundamental nature is constant and
unchanging.
1293:
To have a better understanding of the connection between our
perceptions of this phenomenal world and its true reality, we
1294:
need to talk about the theory of the two truths, relative truth and
absolute truth.
1295: Everything has an absolute aspect, or absolute truth, and a relative
1296: aspect, or relative truth. The absolute or ultimate truth is about
1297:
the inherent nature of everything, how things really are. The
conventional or relative truth is about how things appear. We
1298: ordinary people may perceive sort of relative truth, that is, the
1299: relative world in all its diversity, through our everyday use of mind
1300: and our sense faculties. We do not usually consider the objects
1301:
of our senses, what we see, hear, taste, smell, and touch, to be
devoid of intrinsic existence. The everyday world is something
1302:
we consider to be absolutely, independently existing. However,
it is only through rigorous and penetrating analysis are we able
1303:
to understand absolute truth, the true nature of all things and
phenomena. And only through our own Dharma practice can we
1304:
reveal the tenuousness and relativity hidden from their appearance
and realize the truly empty nature of all phenomena.
1305:
Generally speaking, our mundane mind tends to understand the
two truths as two separate, independent things, but actually they
1307: are two aspects of a single reality. From seeing only relative truth,
1308:
we will eventually reach a profound certainty in the meaning
of absolute truth. From understanding and further realizing the
1309: meaning of absolute truth, we will become more careful of our
1310: actions, speeches and thoughts. Relative truth functions inexorably
1311:
within absolute truth. A thorough realization of the empty nature
of all phenomena has never led anyone to think that positive
1312:
actions do not bring happiness, or that negative actions do not
bring suﬀering. All phenomena appear from within emptiness as a
1313: result of the coming together of illusory causes and conditions. The
1314:
inﬁnite display of phenomena can arise only because everything is
empty in nature. As Nagarjuna said:
1315:
Only by things being empty,
   Can things be possible at all.
1316:
Padmasambhava also said, “Although my view is higher than
the sky, my attention to actions and their eﬀects is ﬁner than
1317:
ﬂour.” When our realization of emptiness becomes as vast as the
sky, we will gain an even greater conviction about the law of
1318:
cause and eﬀect, and we will see just how important our conduct
really is. Likewise, if we have a thorough understanding of the
1319:
way phenomena appear through dependent arising, it will not
be diﬃcult for us to understand the view of emptiness while
1320:
89
remaining in meditation. On arising from such a meditation, we
1321: will recognize clearly the direct relationship between actions and
1322:
their results. This will enable us to discriminate easily between

1323: Once we realize the true nature of emptiness, our perception would

be simply like what Thogme Zangpo once said in a humble way,
“All the joys and suﬀerings of this world are just projections of

1354:
Therefore, Shariputra, all phenomena are emptiness, that

1355: stains, no purity, no increase, no decrease.
1357: The Tibetan and the Chinese versions of this passage are diﬀerent
1358: in some respects. In the Tibetan version, it is eight profundities
1359: that are beyond all conceptual elaborations: (1) emptiness, (2) no
1360: characteristics, (3) no production, (4) no cessation, (5) no stains,
1361:
(6) no purity, (7) no increase, and (8) no decrease. Yet several
Chinese translations only mention seven profundities. For this
1362: reason, Khenpo Sodargye explained this teaching as the sevenfold
1363:
profundity, in which, the ﬁrst and second is combined as one, the
emptiness of characteristics.
1365: This means that not only are all things empty of inherent nature,
1366: but also their very characteristics are emptiness. Like in the Dia-
1367: mond Sutra it is said, “All appearances are illusory.” Ordinary living
1368: beings believe that all appearance, such as sound, form or taste,
1369: possess essential characteristics that are pleasant to hear, beautiful
1370: to behold, and delicious to taste, and that such characteristics
1371:
92
are truly existent, so they strongly cling to such characters. On
1372:
the surface everything has characteristics, such as men, women,
mountains, rivers, and planet, each and every thing has its own
1373:
characteristic way of appearing. But indeed, this is a mere des-
ignation, fabricated by a conceptual thought. If we understand
1374: this point, we will easily understand that a subject, that is, the
1375:
apprehender of characteristics, is also nonexistent. Thus, we will
ascertain the fundamental entity of all things as emptiness.
1377:
On the surface, all things possess the appearance of being pro-
duced by the gathering of causes and conditions. For example,
1378:
the production of the new sprouts in the spring; the production
of fresh, blooming ﬂowers and lush vegetation in the summer;
1379: the production of ripe fruit and the leaves turning red in the fall;
1380: the production of the pure, white snow in the winter, etc. Indeed,
1381: the productions of all these things only belong to the illusion of
1382:
the ordinary people, because ultimately speaking, there is no real
production.
1383:
Some may wonder, “Is not everything continually being produced
and ceasing?” Indeed, these appearances are merely posited on
1384: a conventional level. When we engage genuine observation, such
1385: production cannot have a real existence. For example, if the causal
1387: element exists at a former time, then the eﬀect element will exist at
1388: a later time. Consequently, at the very time when the result element
1389: is produced, the causal element will have ceased. Therefore, it is
1390: not established that eﬀects are produced from causes. If causes and
1391: eﬀects are established simultaneously, we then incur in the fault
1392:
of limitless production. Hence, what we refer to as production is
fundamentally nonexistent.
1393: Since the production of all things, is nonexistent, then abiding in
1394: the middle, and cessation in the end, cannot exist either. From
1395: this, we can understand that all things are indeed nonexistence.
1396: The three characteristics of production, abiding, and cessation, are
1397:
only ascertained from the conventional perspective of conditioned
things.
1399: The term “stains” means deﬁlement, that is, belonging to samsara.
1400: On a ﬁrst glance, samsara exists. Each of the living beings of the
1401: six realms of samsara, together with the suﬀering they experience,
1402: their modes of subsistence and their environments, are existent.
1403: However, if we observe things in detail, the six realms of samsara
1404: are nothing but the deluded appearances of sentient beings. The
1405: term “purity” refers to nirvana. Prior to analysis, nirvana does exist.
1406: Again, when ascertained from the perspective of its fundamental
1407:
94
entity, nirvana is also nonexistent. Hence, both samsara, which is
1408:
deﬁled, and nirvana, which is pure and free from deﬁlement, are
nonexistent.
1410: From the perspective of the resultant state, these two terms convey
1411: that ultimate reality has no real existence. From the perspective of
1412: samsara, they illustrate that both the increase of aﬄictions and the
1413: decrease of merit are nonexistent. From the perspective of nirvana,
1414:
they illustrate that both the increase of merit and the decrease of
aﬄictions and obstructions are nonexistent.
1415:
In general, as long as living beings remain on the level of the
unawakened, aﬄictions and obstructions such as desire, hatred,
1416:
and ignorance, will increase in their mental continuum, while
virtues such as great compassion, the wisdom of non-duality, and
1417: the mind of awakening, will diminish. As they gradually approach
1418:
Buddhahood, both the aﬄictive obstructions and the obstructions
to omniscience will gradually decrease and become eventually
1419:
destroyed, while the uncommon, ocean-like virtues of a buddha
will increase evermore.
1420:
However, this explanation is conﬁned to the mere perspective
of the appearing aspect. If we engage the perspective of the real
1421: aspect of all things, increase and decrease turn out to be merely our
1423: conceptual thoughts. In reality, there is absolutely neither increase
1424: nor decrease. Just like a great ocean, where the waves rise and fall
1425: without increasing or decreasing the level of water in the ocean,
1426: when living beings become buddhas, their virtues will not expand,
1427:
and when they are not buddhas yet, their virtues will not diminish.
In this way, there is nothing to increase or decrease.
1428:
All buddhas and bodhisattvas have had a personal realization
of the truth concerning the emptiness of characteristics of all
1429: things, free from conceptual elaboration. Therefore, the bodhisattva
1430: Avalokiteshvara can convey its profound meaning to Shariputra. As
1431: beginners in the study of the Prajnaparamita, we should understand
1432: the profound meaning of these teachings. We should not have blind
1433: faith in them with a lack of understanding, neither be dubious
1434: about them for no good reason. Instead, having heard the teachings
1435:
on emptiness, we should try to gain personal experience through
listening, reﬂection, and meditation.
1436:
In the foregoing, we have ascertained the subject matter of the
foundational, or natural, Prajnaparamita.
1438:

F1. Determine the Nature of the Five Aggregates as Emptiness
1439:
Therefore, Shariputra, in emptiness there is no form, no
   feelings, no perceptions, no mental formations, and no
1441: Therefore: According the analysis of the natural or foundational
1442:
Prajnaparamita, we can understand that the ﬁve aggregates, which
include all the conditioned phenomena, do not truly exist. All
1443:
the unconditioned phenomena do not exist either, for they are
just conceptions based on the conditioned phenomena. So all the
1444:
knowable things are by nature empty, and from here, we can easily
understand that twelve sense bases, eighteen elements, twelve
1445:
links of dependent origination, as well as four noble truths do not
truly exist, too.
1447:
[...] in emptiness there is no form, no feelings, no perceptions, no
mental formations, and no consciousness.
1448: As we’ve understood that form is emptiness and emptiness is
1449: form, so within emptiness, there’re no forms truly existing with an
1450: essential entity. Likewise, within emptiness, there’re no feelings,
1451:
perceptions, mental formations, or consciousness truly existing
with an essential entity.
1452: Some may wonder, in the previous text, it is already said that feel-
1453: ings, perceptions, mental formations, and consciousness are empty,
1454: why is it repeated here one more time? As we can see, according
1455: to the textual outline, the previous sentence is the determination
1456: from the perspective of the foundational Prajnaparamita, and here
1457: it is analyzed from the perspective of the path Prajnaparamita.
1458: Then in the part of the path Prajnaparamita, why did the Buddha
1459:
ﬁrst ascertain the empty nature of ﬁve aggregates? It is because
every living being’s ﬁve aggregates are formed by his or her
1460: own solid habitual tendency, and living beings have the strongest
1461: attachment to their own aggregates. This is the most diﬃcult part
1462: to be abandoned. If living beings are able to realize the nature of
1463:
ﬁve aggregates, then they won’t have any strong attachment to the
other phenomena.
1464:

F2. Determine the Nature of the Twelve Sense Bases as
   Emptiness
1465:
There is no eye, no ear, no nose, no tongue, no body and
   no mind. There is no form, no sound, no smell, no taste, no
1467: The twelve sense bases include two sets of six: six sense organs,
1468: or internal sense bases, which are eye, ear, nose, tongue, body,
1469: mind, and six sense objects, or external sense bases, which are
1470: form, sound, smell, taste, texture, and mental objects. The literal
1471: meaning of sense bases in Tibetan or in Chinese is to take birth,
1472: to erupt. This is because the six consciousnesses are completely
1473:
latent, or inactive, unless erupted through the contact of six sense
organs with their corresponding six objects.
1474:
For instance, when an ear and sound are present, the associated
consciousness arises. The arising of these three elements—ear,
1475: sound and ear consciousness—lead to what is known as contact,
1476: which in turn causes a pleasant or unpleasant or neutral feeling to
1477: arise. It is from such a feeling that craving or aversion arises.
1478: Based on these six pairs of sense bases, a number of mental factors
1479: arise. If we can understand clearly the relationship between these
1480: six pairs, or how consciousness depends upon contact with its
1481:
99
objects, then we are no longer ignorant and confused about the
1482: relationship between the external and the internal.
1483: Relatively speaking, there are six external bases and six internal
1484:
bases in our phenomenal world; ultimately speaking, however,
through the rigorous observation of their nature, they are empty.
1485: For example, when we hear a sound, we may feel either pleasant
1486: or unpleasant or neutral; but when we analyze its production, its
1487: abiding and its cessation, we cannot ﬁnd an essential entity of this
1488: phenomenon, and the quality of being pleasant or unpleasant only
1489:
depends on observers, and diﬀerent people have diﬀerent feeling
on it.
1490: F3. Determine the Nature of the Eighteen Elements as Emptiness
1491:
There is no eye-element, up to and including no element of
   mental consciousness.
1492:
Here element means seed, something very fundamental which
bears its own nature and has its own type of potential. The eighteen
1493: elements are nothing but twelve sense bases plus their correspond-
1494: ing six resultant consciousnesses, which arise out of the contact
1495: between the six sense organs and their corresponding six objects.
1496: They describe the participating factors in perception: subject and
1497: object, and in between, which form three sets of six each. The three
1498:
100
sets are labelled the outer elements, inner elements, and secret
1499:
elements, and their respective six subdivisions all correspond to
the six diﬀerent senses.
1500: The six outer elements relating to external things correspond to
1501: the six objects of form, sound, smell, taste, touch, and mind. The
1502:
six inner elements are related to the eye, ear, nose, tongue, body,
and mind organs. They are composed of both mind and matter,
1503:
and therefore are positioned between the subject (secret) and the
object (outer) elements.
1504: It is important to note that the sense organ itself is diﬀerent from the
1505:
sense consciousness. The organ merely supports its corresponding
consciousness. For example, when we say “the eye sees”, we are
1506:
not being entirely correct. It is our eye consciousness, not the organ,
which is doing the seeing.
1507:
101
If we understand the empty nature of twelve sense bases, which
1508: means the six sense organs do not exist, and their objects, the
1509: six external bases do not exist either, then consequently, the six
1510: resultant consciousnesses that are formed through the contact of
1511: six sense organs and their corresponding objects do not exist too.
1512: Therefore, ultimately speaking, there’re no eighteen elements.
1513: The non-existence of the eighteen elements does not deny their
1514:
appearance in front of us ordinary beings. However, at this very
moment they appear, their nature are empty, and emptiness is
1515: exactly the nature of their appearance. In other words, we cannot
1516:
ﬁnd this so called emptiness somewhere else besides appearance,
and neither can we ﬁnd appearance besides emptiness. Emptiness
1517:
and appearance are in perfect union, appearance is not other than
emptiness, and emptiness is not other than appearance.
1518: Therefore, the non-existence of ﬁve aggregates, twelve sense bases,
1519: or eighteen elements is not the ultimate meaning of the Heart
1520: Sutra, because it is just one of the four extremes. It is called similar
1521: emptiness, because it’s closer to the ultimate meaning of emptiness,
1522: and especially for those living beings who have very strong habitual
1523: tendency of clinging, non-existence can be the best starting point
1524:
to understand the meaning of emptiness. Eventually, we need to
break through all the four extremes of our conceptual thought.
1525:
102
The ultimate meaning of the Heart Sutra is the perfect union of
1526: emptiness and appearance. Just like within a dream, there are all
1527:
kinds of vivid appearances, however, those appearances are just
illusions and once waking up from the dream, everything is gone
1528: and it is so obvious that none of those appearances possesses an
1529: essential and solid entity. Likewise, all the manifestations within
1530:
samsara only possess the true nature of emptiness, and within
emptiness there’re all kinds of appearances; once waking up from
1531:
our own illusion, we will realize that the appearances within
samsara do not possess any essential entity, and we cannot ﬁnd
