F4. Determine the Nature of the Twelve Links of Dependent
   Origination as Emptiness
1534:
There is no ignorance, and there is no extinction of igno-
   rance, up to and including no aging and death, and no ex-
1536: This sentence refers to the twelve links of dependent origination in
1537: the chain of causation. It is a summary in accordance with their
1538:
sequence of evolution within the chain of samsaric existence, by
which all the ﬁve aggregates, twelve sense bases, and eighteen
1539:
elements interact to keep sentient beings bound in the cycle of
samsaric existence, a cycle of suﬀering. Although just two are
1540:
103
mentioned speciﬁcally, the phrase “up to and including” actually
1541: includes all the twelve links, which are, ignorance, karmic forma-
1542:
tions, consciousness, name and form, six senses, contact, feelings,
craving, clinging, becoming, birth, and aging and death.
1543:
As the Buddha taught us, there are outer dependent origination
and inner dependent origination. The former states that a seed
1544: produces its sprout, which gives rise to the stem, and consequently,
1545: the stalk, the fruit, and the leaves. Just as a tree comes into being
1546:
under various causes and conditions, so too does everything. This
is called outer dependent origination.
1547:
What is more important for us is inner dependent origination,
which manifests the way that every sentient being wanders in
1548: samsara in diﬀerent living forms. A human being in this life may
1549: become an animal in the afterlife, and then turn into a heavenly
1550: being in the next one. Before achieving liberation, reincarnation
1551: from life to life will continue. Such a life process can be well under-
1552: stood by following the teaching of the twelve links of dependent
1553: origination. If we don’t understand these twelve links, we cannot
1554:
fully understand the reality of reincarnation, nor can we generate
true compassion toward others.
1555:
104
The Cycle of the Twelve Links of Dependent
Origination
1556: In this cycle of samsaric existence, the ﬁrst point that we should
1557: know is ignorance, and it is the root cause of samsara. Ignorance
1558: can be indicated by self-attachment, that is to say, every living
1559:
being clings to “I” and “what I have”, which is the root cause
of samsara. So ignorance is the ﬁrst link of the twelve links of
1560: dependent origination. Or sometimes we can directly say that
1561: ignorance refers to a mental state that we are ignorant to the truth.
1562: Being ignorant and deluded, one can’t see the truth and just ends
1563:
up with wrong actions. That is, driven by self-attachment, one
will create all kinds of good and bad karma through body, speech
1564:
and mind. This is the second link of the twelve, called karmic
formation. We may not exactly be aware of ignorance and karmic
1565: formation in this life, but they were generated in the past lives and
1566:
are the causes that drive us to come to this world in this present
life.
1567: Karmic formation gives rise to consciousness, the third link, which
1568: carries all good and bad karma. Consciousness continuously exists
1569: life after life. Unlike the body, which rots away completely after
1570: death, consciousness keeps going on by taking diﬀerent living
1571: forms. For example, in the bardo stage, there’s only consciousness
1572:
105
and no physical body, and due to the previous karma, conscious-
1573: ness will perceive diﬀerent scenarios and choose the pleasant one
1574:
to be its destination, where the consciousness is bound with a
physical body and starts its next life.
1575: If it is viviparity, consciousness will descend into a womb and
1576: gives rise to name and form, the fourth link of the twelve. “Name”
1577: refers to the four aggregates of feelings, perception, formation and
1578: consciousness. “Form” is the aggregate of forms and refers to the
1579:
physical body before it takes shape. Starting from consciousness,
they are the eﬀects of the chain in the present life.
1580: The ﬁfth one is called “six sense bases”, which means that after
1581: consciousness is linked to a womb, the six sense organs, namely,
1582: eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind will gradually take shape
1583:
inside the womb. So the ﬁfth factor is called “six sense bases”, or
“six sense gates”.
1584:
The coming together of six sense organs, six objects, and six
corresponding consciousnesses is called contact, and it is the
1585: sixth link of the twelve. Six objects include forms, sounds, smells,
1586: tastes, texture, and mental objects. The seventh link is feelings,
1587: resulting from the contact of sense organs and their respective
1588: objects. Feelings describes three diﬀerent mental states. Toward
1589: favorable objects, one has pleasant feelings. Toward unfavorable
1590:
106
objects, one has unpleasant feelings. And toward neither favorable
1591:
nor unfavorable objects, one has neutral feelings, which is actually
a mental state of ignorance.
1592: These ﬁve links result from the causes generated in the past lives
1593:
and are the eﬀects of this present life. They consequently lead
to the next three: craving, clinging, and becoming, which also
1594: belong to this life. Craving, the eighth link, means that one is
1595: eager to experience pleasant feelings and unwilling to experience
1596: unpleasant ones, which involves desire, aversion and ignorance.
1597: Craving plays a role equivalent to the ﬁrst link, ignorance, and
1598: further develops into clinging, which means actively striving for
1599: what is pleasurable and avoiding what is painful. This is the ninth
1600: link, equivalent to the second link of karmic formation. Craving
1601: and clinging lead to the tenth link of becoming and all three are
1602: the causes of the next life, which means one acts with body, speech
1603:
and mind in the present life and creates the karma that determines
one’s next birth, the eleventh link of the twelve.
1604:
No matter whether one is reborn as a human or other sentient
being and no matter where one is reborn, birth is always followed
1605: by aging and death, the twelfth link. Each of us is destined to age
1606: and what we are doing now is conditioning and forming the next
1607:
life. It keeps going on and on, and the wheel of life will never stop
until we attain liberation.
1608:
107
The Meaning of the Twelve Links of Dependent
Origination
1609:
The twelve links of dependent origination explain the whole
procedure of living beings taking birth and rebirth in the endless
1610: cycle of reincarnation. From the perspective of life, they include past
1611: lives, present life and future lives. Ignorance and karmic formation
1612: were caused in past lives, and they produced consciousness, name
1613: and form, six senses, contact, feelings in present life; again the
1614: next three links in the present life, craving, clinging, and becoming
1615: act as the causes of birth, aging and death in future lives. So
1616: brieﬂy speaking, the karma accumulated in past lives is the cause
1617: of the manifestation of the present life, and in turn the karma
1618: accumulated in the present life is the cause of taking rebirth in
1619: future lives. This is exactly the karmic law of causes and eﬀects.
1620:
The twelve links can be classiﬁed into three groups, aﬄictions,
karma and suﬀering. Ignorance, craving and clinging belong to
1621: aﬄictions; karmic formation and becoming belong to karma; and
1622: consciousness, name and form, six senses, contact, feelings, birth,
1623:
and aging and death all belong to suﬀering. Due to aﬄictions
one accumulates karma, and due to karma one has to experience
1624:
suﬀerings; while going through suﬀerings, one again generates
aﬄictions and further accumulates karma. The whole procedure is
1625: such an endless cycle, and the main cause of this cycle is ignorance.
1626:
108
If we are able to get rid of our ignorance and have the wisdom
1627:
to see the truth, then we won’t crave and cling to these deluded
phenomena and eventually break free from the cycle of samsaric
1628:
existence.
The True Nature of the Twelve Links of
Dependent Origination
1629: Generally speaking, the twelve links have the sequence of the
1630: evolution of samsara, as well as the sequence of attaining nirvana.
1631: Although both the process for taking birth in the cycle of existence
1632: and the process of gaining freedom from it do exist on the relative
1633: level, they do not exist on the ultimate level. Furthermore, since they
1634:
do not exist on the ultimate level, their corresponding extinctions,
or non-existence, do not exist either.
1635: For example, ignorance, the ﬁrst link of the twelve, is just a mental
1636: state that is lack of wisdom to see the truth. If we observe its
1637: entity, its origination or its cessation, we just end up with nothing.
1638:
Sometimes ignorance is described as darkness. By turning on
the light, the darkness in a house is immediately dispelled, even
1639:
though the house had remained dark for a thousand years. But
if we try to search how the darkness was produced, and where
1640: it’s gone, we can get nothing. Darkness is just a temporary state
1641: of the house, and has neither birth nor cessation. Or if darkness
1643: really had an essential entity, then there’s no way to dispel it. The
1644: same goes to ignorance. It has no essential entity, and only has a
1645: nature of emptiness. Since the existence of ignorance is empty, the
1646: extinction of ignorance is also empty. That is why in the text, it is
1647: said that there’s no ignorance, and no extinction of ignorance.
1648: The main purpose of the teaching in the Heart Sutra is to destroy
1649: our self-attachment. It is our self-attachment that prevents us from
1650: seeing the truth. If we can get rid of self-attachment, we are no
1651: longer ignorant, and then in turn, without ignorance, we can clearly
1652:
perceive the true nature of all the deluded phenomena in samsara
and won’t be bound in the cycle of suﬀering. So destroying our
1653: self-attachment is the only way to be free from samsara, and the
1654: direct antidote to self-attachment is the wisdom of emptiness. This
1655: is why the reﬂection and meditation on the teaching of emptiness
1656:
are so essential for Dharma practitioners who seek the ultimate
freedom of liberation.
1657:
110
F5. Determine the Nature of the Four Noble Truths as Emptiness
1658:
There is no suﬀering, no origin, no cessation, no path, [...]

The Four Noble Truths
1659:
Here is the negation of the main theme of ﬁrst turning of the
Dharma wheel, the four noble truths, which are, the truth of
1660:
suﬀering, the truth of its origin, the truth of its cessation, and the
truth of the path to its cessation.
1661: First, our present situation, the life in cyclic existence, is suﬀering,
1662:
which needs to be understood. Second, suﬀering has its own root
causes, which are karma and aﬄictions, which need to be aban-
1663: doned. Third, there is a state free from suﬀering which is nirvana,
1664:
the cessation of suﬀering, that can be actualized. And fourth, there
is a path to get there, which needs to be relied upon.
1665: The four truths are the basic foundation of all the Buddha’s teach-
1666: ings. They can be divided into two pairs of cause and eﬀect, known
1667:
as the cause and eﬀect of samsara, thorough aﬄiction, and the
cause and eﬀect of nirvana, complete puriﬁcation.
1669: The ﬁrst noble truth is about the real situation of our life in cyclic
1670: existence, and it is the result of samsara. In order to practice the
1671:
111
path, we must have a clear understanding of suﬀering that pervades
1672: all existence, either sentient or insentient.
1673:
Though we all admit to experiencing sadness and pain in our
lives, it takes further examination for most of us to perceive the
1674:
more subtle modes of suﬀering that shadow even the happiest
occasion. In Buddhist teaching, suﬀering means unsatisfactory,
1675: impermanent, illusive and not controllable. There are three types of
1676: suﬀering, the suﬀering upon suﬀering, the suﬀering of change and
1677: all-pervasive suﬀering of being conditioned. In desire realm, living
1678: beings experience all the three types of suﬀering; in form realm,
1679:
mainly there are the suﬀering of change and all-pervasive suﬀering;
and in formless realm, mainly it’s all-pervasive suﬀering.
1680: The suﬀering upon suﬀering includes all the miseries of the lower
1681: realms, as well as the suﬀerings of birth, aging, sickness and death
1682: in the higher realms, and also separation from loved ones, having
1683:
to encounter what is undesirable, and not achieving what we want
even after pursuing it.
1684: As it is said, “What is the suﬀering upon suﬀering? It is that which is
1685: painful when arising, painful when remaining, and pleasant when
1686: changing.” All these suﬀerings, big or small, are undesirable from
1687: the very ﬁrst moment they appear, and are therefore understood to
1689: be painful. What’s more, there’s one suﬀering coming after another,
1690: one being piled upon another. This is suﬀering upon suﬀering.
1691:
The suﬀering of change means that no matter where we ﬁnd
ourselves, and no matter how seemingly pleasurable and attractive
1692:
our dwelling place, physical body or sensory enjoyments, our
situation cannot possibly remain as it is, but is bound to change,
1693: because of not being beyond the laws of impermanence.
1694: When it does change, what was previously a pleasurable experience
1695: becomes a source of suﬀering. As it is said, “The suﬀering of change
1696:
is that which is pleasant when arising, pleasant when remaining,
but painful when ceasing.”
1697: The all-pervasive suﬀering of being conditioned refers to all experi-
1698: ence that is bound up with the ﬁve aggregates. No matter whether
1699: we are experiencing pleasure or suﬀering, or a neutral state, we
1700: are always setting ourselves up for future suﬀering. Why? Because
1701:
our present aggregates are direct causes for our future aggregates,
which will be the supports for suﬀering in the future.
1702: That means all our present experiences are in some way the causes
1703:
for suﬀerings that will come to us later on. As it is said, “The
suﬀering of being conditioned is not apparent when it arises,
1704: remains or ceases, but it is still the cause of suﬀering.”
1705:
113
2 The Truth of the Origin of Suﬀering
1706:
The second noble truth is the cause of samsara, karma and af-
ﬂictions. Among aﬄictions, ignorance is the most essential one.
1707:
Suﬀering has karmic causes that we accumulate by our own ac-
tivities performed in ignorance. The twelve links of dependent
1708:
origination show us a clear picture of how we are driven by
ignorance and karma and bound in samsara.
1709: 3 The Truth of the Cessation of Suﬀering
1710: Nevertheless, it is possible for us to be free from the cycle of
1711: suﬀering and attain the ultimate peace. The cessation of suﬀering
1712:
is the third noble truth, the result of nirvana. It brings freedom
from suﬀering and the cause of suﬀering.
1713: 4 The Truth of the Path to the Cessation of Suﬀering
1714: The cessation of suﬀering cannot be attained without any cause.
1715: We do need to follow a path in order to achieve this goal. This is
1716:
the fourth noble truth, the path to the cessation of suﬀering, and it
is the cause of nirvana.
1717: There’re many diﬀerent paths that bring about nirvana. For exam-
1718: ple, in pure land tradition, we can chant the name of Amitabha; in
1719: Chan tradition, we can observe our own mind through meditation;
1720: in Vajrayana tradition, we can recognize the nature of mind with the
1721:
114
help of the enlightened master’s direct pointing. Although these
1722: paths are diﬀerent, they share the same goal of achieving nirvana.
1723: Diﬀerent practitioners have diﬀerent capacity and preference, so
1724:
they can choose diﬀerent paths to attain the same enlightenment.
The True Nature of the Four Noble Truths on the
Ultimate Level
1725: On the relative level, the four noble truths really exist, and it is
1726: necessary for us to understand them fully. However, on the ultimate
1727: level, none of them exist. For example, if we believe nirvana as truly
1728: existence, we fall upon the extreme of non-existence, while the
1729: ultimate nirvana is the perfect union of emptiness and luminosity.
1730:
Also, the so called suﬀering does not have a standard measurement,
or a permanent and independent quality. It is just a deluded
1731: feeling based on personal experience. Given the same situation,
1732: some feel it is pleasant, while others feel it is painful. Diﬀerent
1733: feelings only depend on the karmic formation of diﬀerent living
1734: beings. Therefore, suﬀering does not have an intrinsic existence
1735:
that is independent and permanent. So the nature of suﬀering is
emptiness.
1736: We can further understand the four noble truths by using the
1737: metaphor of sickness. We can say that the ﬁrst noble truth diagnoses
1738: a disease. If we want to cure this disease, we must ﬁnd out its cause,
1739:
115
the second noble truth. Once we know the cause, we would be
1740: much happy to follow the prescription and to receive the treatment.
1741: The Buddha is the doctor who diagnoses the disease and prescribes
1742: the medicine. The fourth noble truth, the Dharma path is exactly
1743: the medicine that we need to take to cure the disease. By taking
1744:
the medicine, it will eventually bring us to the state of complete
health, nirvana, the third noble truth of cessation.
1745: Before we are cured, we have to take the medicine, so all the four
1746: noble truths are existent in our spiritual practice. After we are
1747: cured, the sickness is completely gone and there’s no need for us
1748: to keep receiving the treatment. We needn’t cling to the path and
1749:
the recovery state any more. So ultimately speaking, the four noble
truths don’t exist with essential entities.
1750:
116
The Resultant Prajnaparamita


E3. The Resultant Prajnaparamita
1751:
[...] no wisdom, no attainment, and there is also no non-
   attainment.
1752: Now we’re talking about the resultant Prajnaparamita. Here attain-
1753: ment is referred to the fruits that are attained by hearers, solitary
1754: realizers, bodhisattvas, and buddhas. On relative level, there are
1755:
wisdom  that we can attain, and the process of such attainment
does exist. However, on ultimate level, both wisdom and attain-
1756: ment do not exist, and they are only manifested in an illusory and
1757:
dream-like way. So the resultant state of Prajnaparamita is itself
empty of intrinsic existence.
1758: Relatively speaking, the fruit and the person who seek for the fruit
1759: do exist. Without rigorous observation, we can easily say that there
1760:
is such procedure of seeking for the wisdom and merit. However,
in the perception of those enlightened beings who abide in the
1761:
117
realization of emptiness, there is no wisdom and no attainment.
1762: Like in the Diamond Sutra, it is said that in reality, there is no such a
1763: thing called “arhat”, and if an arhat should give rise to the thought,
1764: “I have attained the realization of the arhat”, this means that he is
1765: attached to the notions of a self, and he is not an arhat.
1766: In Vairocana’s commentary, it is also said that because by nature,
1767: all living beings are buddhas, so there’s no new wisdom that a
1768: living being can attain after becoming a buddha. Or in other words,
1769: we already possess the buddha’s vast and profound wisdom and
1770:
qualities in a perfect way, so there’s no new attainment needed any
more.
1771:
No non-attainment means that because there’s no attainment, so
the other corresponding extreme, non-attainment doesn’t exist
1772: either. Or another way to understand it can be referred to the
1773:
relative truth, in which the paths and the resultant states of the
paths exist in a dream-like way.
1774:
118
The Merit and Fruit of the
Realization of Emptiness
1775: D3. The Merit of the Realization of Emptiness
1776:
Therefore, Shariputra, because they have no attainment, all
   bodhisattvas depend on the perfection of wisdom and abide
1777:
in it. Their mind is unobstructed, so they have no fear, and
   having passed beyond error, they will enter into ﬁnal nir-
1779: Since bodhisattvas have no attainment, they rely on the perfection
1780:
of wisdom and abide in it and they don’t have any obscuration
in their minds. Here unobstructed means the mind has become
1781: totally cleansed of all mental aﬄictions. When an individual goes
1782:
through a process of purifying the mind by applying the antidotes
to the mental aﬄictions, over time, the mind becomes totally
1783: free of all these obscurations. Essentially speaking, only through
1784: actualizing the empty nature of the mind can one clean away all
1785:
119
mental aﬄictions and attain liberation. As Nagarjuna explains in
1786: his Fundamentals of the Middle Way, emptiness is both the means of
1787:
eliminating the mental aﬄictions and the resultant state that one
arrives at after having done so.
1788: Having no obscuration in their minds, they have no fear. Fear is
1789: resulted from our obscuration, our mental aﬄictions that mislead
1790: us to consider everything as truly existence. According to some
1791: great masters’ teaching in the Han tradition, there are ﬁve types of
1792: fear, the fear of not well living, the fear of bad reputation, the fear
1793:
of death, the fear of taking rebirth in three lower realms, and the
fear of others’ power.
1794: As long as we have self-attachment, we are concerned about gain
1795:
and loss, and such kind of concern generates fear in our minds.
Through the realization of emptiness, we can reach the state of
1796: total equanimity in all situations. As a result, there is neither hope
1797:
nor fear, neither demons nor gods. This is the ultimate level of
fearlessness.
1798: So overall speaking, the true way that we exist is the way the
1799: reﬂection of the moon in water exists, and the true way we expe-
1800:
rience is the way the dreamer experiences. As we either struggle
through our dreams or enjoy them, we do so on the assumption
1801: that what is happening is real and true in an absolute sense. But
1802:
120
it is true only from the context of that dream. When we awaken,
1803:
everything we have just experienced are just an illusion based on
emptiness. Likewise, we think we have awakened from a dream
1804: into a more real “reality”, but in fact, as we pass from sleeping to
1805: waking we have simply shifted from one dreamlike state to another.
1806: Our waking perceptions are all merely the manifestation of mental
1807:
habitual tendency and karmic patterns accumulated over inﬁnite
lifetimes.
1808:
[...] having passed beyond error, they will enter into ﬁnal
nirvana.
1809: And having utterly passed beyond error, one will reach the end of
1810:
nirvana. Here error means ordinary beings’ deluded perceptions
due to ignorance. For us deluded beings, we assume impermanence
1811:
as permanence, suﬀering as happiness, no-self as the existence
of self, and impurity as purity. All of these misunderstanding
1812:
are caused by our own ignorance. Driven by such erroneous
understanding, all living beings are trapped in samsara and have
1813:
to take rebirth in any of the six realms, and set oﬀ on an endless
journey of suﬀering.
1814: Nirvana can be understood as the ultimate nature of one’s mind
1815: that is completely free from all mental aﬄictions. There are natural
1816: nirvana and resultant nirvana. Since all the aspects of one’s path
1817:
121
to enlightenment—one’s innate capacity to attain enlightenment
1818: through the path, the path itself, and the results of the path to
1819:
enlightenment—are devoid of intrinsic existence, they all possess
natural nirvana.
1820:
Through cultivating insight into the nature of emptiness, one
will be able to dispel and overcome the suﬀerings resulting from
1821:
the erroneous understandings of things and phenomena that
result from fundamental ignorance. Not only can the suﬀerings
1822:
be removed, but even the propensity for self-grasping ignorance
and the imprints left by past ignorant actions can be removed.
1823: Thus, one can completely eliminate ignorance in the present, the
1824: imprints of it from the past, and the propensity toward ignorance
1825: in the future. Transcending all ignorance, one naturally becomes
1826:
free of fear, and one abides in the ﬁnal nirvana of a buddha, which
is the resultant nirvana.
1827: D4. The Fruit of the Realization of Emptiness
1828:
All the buddhas of the three times have awakened to sup-
   reme, perfect, and complete enlightenment by depending
1830:
Here the term three times refers to all buddhas throughout the
universe. Certainly in their own perception, there’re no such
1831:
122
conception of time and space, and the state of buddhahood is
1832: beyond the conﬁnement of time and space. This term used here is
1833:
from the perspective of ordinary people’s perception, in order to
emphasize all buddhas.
1834:
The fruit of the realization of emptiness is the unsurpassable
buddhahood. Without fear or obscurations, without the slightest
1835:
concept about their meditative states, the buddhas of the past,
present, and future apply these Prajnaparamita practices and
1836: realize perfect enlightenment. Not only ordinary living beings
1837: and bodhisattvas need to solely rely on Prajnaparamita to achieve
1838:
nirvana, all the buddhas of the ten directions and three times
also manifested in this way to achieve the supreme, perfect, and
1839: complete enlightenment. Therefore, Prajnaparamita is the only way
1840:
of becoming buddha, and each living being must follow this path
and depend on Prajnaparamita to break free from samsara, and
1841:
as a result, to attain the complete enlightenment and the ultimate
liberation.
1843: D5. The Mantra with Great Blessings
1844:
Therefore, one should know that the great mantra of the
   perfection of wisdom, the mantra of great knowledge, the
1845: supreme mantra, the mantra that is equal to the unequaled,
1846: is the mantra that paciﬁes all suﬀering, and it is true because
1847:
it is not deceptive. The mantra of the perfection of wisdom
   was then stated:
1848: tadyatha gate gate paragate parasamgate bodhi svaha!
1849: The perfection of wisdom itself, the Prajnaparamita, is here referred
1850: to as the “great mantra”. The meaning of mantra is to protect the
1851: mind or the mind stream. Thus, through attaining the perfection of
1852: wisdom, one’s mind will be completely protected against erroneous
1853: beliefs, against the mental aﬄictions that arise from such beliefs,
1854:
124
and against the suﬀering produced by the mental aﬄictions. It will
1855: lead to the ultimate destination of enlightenment.
1856:
The perfection of wisdom is called the “mantra of great knowl-
edge” because thoroughly understanding its meaning eliminates
1857:
the three poisons of craving, hatred, and ignorance. It transforms
beginningless darkness into the state of great awareness.
1858:
It is called the “supreme mantra” because there is no greater
method than the perfection of wisdom for saving one from the
1859:
extremes of cyclic existence and the isolated peace of individual
nirvana.
1860: It is called the mantra “equal to the unequalled” because the
1861: Buddha’s enlightened state is unequalled. The state of buddhahood,
1862: or the state of equanimity, is known as the state without equal,
1863:
and, through the deepest realization of this mantra, one attains a
state equal to that state.
1864:
Finally, the perfection of wisdom is known as the mantra that
“paciﬁes all suﬀering” because it calms all suﬀerings and also
1865: removes all propensities for future suﬀering.
1866: The perfection of wisdom is the ultimate truth, so “it is true”.
1867: In the realm of the ultimate truth, there is no disparity between
1869:
appearance and reality, and thus this ultimate truth is “not decep-
tive”.
1870:
The mantra of the perfection of wisdom was then stated:
tadyatha gate gate paragate parasamgate bodhi svaha!
1871: In Sanskrit, tadyatha literally means “it is thus” and prepares the
1872:
way for what follows; gate gate means “go, go”; paragate means
“go beyond”; parasamgate means “go totally beyond”; and bodhi
1873: svaha can be read as “be rooted in the ground of enlightenment”.
1874: Thus, the entire mantra itself can be translated as “go, go, go be-
1875: yond, go totally beyond, be rooted in the ground of enlightenment”.
1876: We can interpret this mantra metaphorically to read “go to the
1877: other shore”, which is to say, abandon this shore of samsara, unen-
1878: lightened existence, which has been our home since beginningless
1879:
time, and cross to the other shore of ﬁnal nirvana and complete
liberation.
1880: Sometimes people may think that a mantra is just composed of cer-
1881:
tain types of syllables pronounced by human beings, and through
chanting this mantra, the corresponding deity will come to oﬀer
1882: help through his miraculous power. Actually this is not the proper
1883: view on mantra. Ultimately speaking, a mantra has no diﬀerence
1884: with its deity, or in other words, a mantra is exactly the manifesta-
1885: tion of the deity. For example, when we chant om mani padme hum,
1886:
126
this mantra is exactly the manifestation of Avalokiteshvara, and
1888:
127
Encourage to Learn and
Practice Prajnaparamita
1889: D6. Encourage to Learn and Practice Prajnaparamita
1890:
Shariputra, a bodhisattva, a great being, should train in the
   profound perfection of wisdom in this way.”
1891:
In Avalokiteshvara’s ﬁnal statement, he oﬀers encouragement
to Shariputra, as well as to all the followers of this sutra. All
1892:
bodhisattvas wishing to attain the full enlightenment must practice
according to the profound transcendent wisdom, which breaks
1893:
down all conceptual thoughts and ego-clinging in the ground of
samsara and nirvana.
1894: It is quite essential that each of us who wish to achieve enlighten-
1895: ment must engage in the practice of the Prajnaparamita. As taught
1896: by the great bodhisattva Maitreya, there are three types of root
1897: causes for attaining the path of seeing, or becoming a bodhisattva
1899: who arrives the ﬁrst bhumi. They are: 1) giving the teaching of the
1900: Prajnaparamita to others; 2) helping others to achieve the realiza-
1901: tion of the Prajnaparamita; 3) engaging in the meditation practice
1902: of the Prajnaparamita. All of these three root causes will generate
1903:
incredible merit and lead practitioners to achieve the realization of
the Prajnaparamita.
1904:
129
Dispel Doubt through the
Buddha’s Affirmation
1905: B2. Dispel Doubt through the Buddha’s Aﬃrmation
1906:
At that time, the Exalted One emerged from that concentra-
   tion and said to Avalokiteshvara, the bodhisattva, the great
1907: being: “Well done, well done, son of noble qualities, it is just
1908: so; it should be just so. The perfection of wisdom should be
1909:
practiced just as you said. The tathagatas will also rejoice in
   this.”
1910: The Buddha, arising from his samadhi, expresses his own appre-
1911:
ciation for the ﬂawless eﬀorts of Avalokiteshvara and Shariputra.
Up to this point, the Buddha has been deeply immersed in med-
1912:
itative absorption on the apprehension of the profound. During
his meditation, the Buddha inspires Avalokiteshvara and Sharipu-
1913:
tra to engage in the foregoing dialogue. When their dialogue is
concluded, the Buddha commends and aﬃrms Avalokiteshvara’s
1914:
130
expression. Here the Buddha reveals that he was both aware
1915: of and participating in all the aspects of their dialogue. At the
1916:
Buddha’s level, there is no distinction between meditative and
post-meditative states. This aﬃrmation indicates that Buddha’s
1917: meditative absorption is in fact a fusion of both deep meditative
1918:
concentration on emptiness—ultimate truth, and full awareness of
the world of phenomena continually unfolding—relative truth.
1919:
So why does the Buddha need to aﬃrm this dialogue? According
to some commentaries, there are three reasons. The ﬁrst one is
1920: to dispel the doubt of Shariputra, because he may wonder if he
1921: brought up a proper question; the second one is to dispel the doubt
1922: of Avalokiteshvara, because he may wonder if he answered the
1923: question in a proper way; and the third one is to dispel the doubts
1924:
of the audience, because they may also wonder if the dialogue
between Avalokiteshvara and Shariputra is a proper teaching on
1925:
the Prajnaparamita. With the Buddha’s aﬃrmation in the end of
the sutra, all of these doubts are completely dispelled, and the
1926:
audience understand that this dialogue really has no diﬀerence
with the teaching given by the Buddha himself.
1927: The tathagatas will also rejoice in this.
1928:
131
The Buddha also oﬀers the praise and encouragement of all bud-
1929:
dhas of the three times and ten directions for all those endeavoring
to practice the Prajnaparamita.
1930:
132
Praise and Rejoice
Praise and Rejoice


A3. Praise and Rejoice
1931:
Then, having the Buddha spoken these words, the venera-
   ble Shariputra and the bodhisattva, the great being, the no-
1932:
ble Avalokiteshvara, with all beings of the world including
   gods, humans, asuras and gandharvas, heard the Buddha’s
1933:
discourse with great joy, received it with conviction, and
   promised to engage in practice.
1934:
In the end it is universal rejoicing in the Buddha’s profound
teaching. As we can see, within the assembly, there are gods,
1935: humans, asuras, gandharvas and numerous living beings in the
1936: world. This essential teaching beneﬁts all beings without exception
1937: and all beings are considered equal by the Buddha. It is because
1938: all beings equally possess buddha nature, a precious treasure as
1939: yet undiscovered, which they can ﬁnally recognize by cultivating
1940: wisdom and compassion on the path. This is cause for rejoicing.
1941:
134
The last sentence, “received it with conviction, and promised
1942: to engage in practice”, shows us the right path to follow the
1943: teaching. First, we need to receive the teaching through listening
1944:
and reﬂecting, during which stage we should be able to dispel all
our ignorance, wrong views and doubts regarding the teaching
1945: and develop sincere conviction to the teaching. Second, based on
1946: such conviction, we need to put this teaching into practice through
1947:
meditation and eventually realize the teaching on our own, which
is the ultimate goal of the path.
1949:
May the merit resulting from this piece of work contribute
in the greatest possible measure to the long life of all great
1950:
masters, to the ﬂourishing of the Buddha Dharma, and to
           the welfare of all sentient beings.
1951: It is always our wish to present a work of the highest quality to the
1952:
readers so that anyone who reads this text would ﬁnd inspiration.
So we would very much appreciate your comments, feedback or
1953:
suggestions for how this text might be improved and made more
 valuable. You are also greatly welcomed if you want to make a
1954:
contribution to any of our other projects of translation.
